text: (375ml bottle from boxbeers.dk) Pours a slightly hazy ruby-brown with a quite large cream head that fades slowly leaving lace. Aroma of quite sour cherries, lots of wood, red wine vinegar, cherry pits, horseblanket Brett, lemon, spicebox, light caramel malt sweetness. Flavour of tart cherry, lemon, quite strongly woody, tangy astringent quality, some dusty yeast, light caramel sweetness, soft spice notes, maybe a touch of hard cheese. Finish is dry, low lingering fruity tartness, lots of oak. Light to medium bodied with smooth soft carbonation. The overall feeling does belie the relatively low ABV, but with that under consideration its a quite drinkable sour red.
Thanks Carl! Fantastic sour! Big bright cherry and other dark fruit with funk and tart nicely in balance. Moderate mouthfeel that sipped smooth.

Hazy cider/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of woody malt, yeast, sour cherries, vanilla, & spice; Flavor of slight sweet malt, yeast, oak, sour dark fruit (notably cherries), raisons, and spice; Finish is dry & sour/tart; Very nicely balanced; Nice aroma - well made sour ale.
Bottle from ck1, shared by all on poker night. Thanks! Dry. Red. Quite oaky, slightly hoppy. Somewhat fruity, sweet malts are fairly subtle. Overall solid and tasty. 14.3
Hazy brown with a light tan head. Sour cherries, musty farmhouse, some sweet fruit, some caramel, light earth notes. Finish is long and semi-dry. Very nice.

Keg at Ratebeer Best Beer Festival. 31/01/2016. A murky brown / onion skin coloured pour with a loose white head. Aroma is tangy sour, lemon, horsey funk, sweet and sour with woody notes. Flavour is composed of brown sugars, tangy sour, cinamon spices, biscuity malts, dusty musty sourness. Palate is dry and tangy, moderate carbonation, approachable sourness. Good.

375ml bottle shared @Pułapka, Gdańsk
Red fruit (cherry) aroma over slight vinegar. Very nice funk. Taste is cherry pit sour, slight bitterness in the finish. Very drinkable.

Flaska systembolaget. Grumlig rödbrunlila kulör med knappt något skum. Mogen doft av fat, trä, kryddor och svarta körsbär och röda bär. Syrlig och torr munkänsla med mycket bär. Hallon och körsbär med viss knäckighet

375ml bottle from Systembolaget. Hazy dark brown, small tanned head, some lacing. Mature oaky aroma, tart cherries, red wine vinegar, yellow cheese and mild funk. Medium to full bodied, tart, rich and smooth mouthfeel. Tart, and yeasty peppery taste, cheese, cherries, great rich taste from the oak barrels. Long tart and dry finish. Very drinkable!

Bottle enjoyed at home
Dark red, opaque, nice tanned head. Smell of caramel, funk, red berries, cherries, oak, barnyard, quite inviting. Light sweet, fruity, cherries, medium sour, nice acids, quite funky, alot of farm flavors, complex overall. Moderate bitter, cherry stone tail. Very nice stuff
On tap at Beer Junction. Pours a hazy reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma is cherries and barrel. Taste is similar with bready notes. Refreshing, pleasant.
Loved it, very nice one, acidic, cherry like, hints of barrell, generally huge beer.

From a bottle into a snifter. Brown body somewhat clear, tan head, reddish hue. Nose is cherries, sour, brown sugar. Light body, good carbonation, long sour note. Nicely balanced, interesting and unique beer.
Pours as a very murky red colour with no head. Not too bad as sours go. Not unpleasantly cheek clenching! Does have a bit of a sour cherry taste. (K)

Aromat świeżo wyciśniętego soku z wiśni, lekka stajnia w tle, do tego odrobina nut beczkowych i pestkowych. W smaku dość mocno kwaśne (ale brak tutaj jakichkolwiek nut octowych), bardzo owocowe, wiśniowe, czuć też porzeczkę i trochę nut dzikich (jest słynny spocony koń :) ). W fniszu beczka, drewno, lekka pestkowość i odrobina słodyczy (to chyba ten mak). 
Bardzo dobry kwach, zbalansowany, przemyślany, zarówno do chlania hektolitrami jak i do spokojnej degustacji.

Bottle from The Confessional. Delightful cherry/oak aroma. Pours dark brown. A cherry, oak, light vinegar, poppy taste but super light on the palate. Not nearly as complex as any of the Rodenbachs or even a Duchesse. If this beer tasted anywhere near its aroma it would be world class, but as it stands it is an above average but crazy overpriced sour brown (a Rodenbach Grand Cru can be had for less than 1/3 the price). No idea how this beer is rated so high -- in contrast to the Cuvée de Tomme, which is superb -- maybe the reviewers here havent had the real thing from Belgium?

Bottle. Sensoric. Deep brown with moderate, frothy, light brown, semi-thick head. Poor head retention and lacing. Light to moderate malty aromas, caramel, heavy yeasty, some strong barnyard notes, acidic, some berries in the background. Taste is moderately sweet, moderate acidic with some light bitterness, finish is very dry, moderately acidic with wooden accents. Medium body, creamy and oily texture, average to lively carbonation, finish is light to moderately acidic, slightly bitter, woody and dry. In overall quite different sour brown ale that I used to drink. First of all poppy seeds give this brew some light bitterness, cherries are not really up for, same as malts. Different than Rodenbachs.

Bottle. Pours cloudy dark amber. Aroma is oak barrel, some wine, light cherry. Body is light, tart and sour. Fizzy carbonation to round of the super refreshing experience of this sour. Still fruity, being light but not lacking taste. Delightful!
Aroma is delicate, flowerish a little bit vinegar. tastes awesome, cherries, very sour, funky. Very good
Tannic, oaky, tart, and dry, with a hint of sour cherry flavor. Very good beer.

Draft Third of a Pint at Route CBC Festival at Craft Beer Co, Clapham, London in Oct 2015 - Reddish Brown in colour. Very fruity, very sour. Tart and sour cherries, oak, vanilla, yeasty, funk. Quite dry. Enjoyable. Lovely Sour Ale! (2015-10-02)

Bottle 
Aroma-cherries, poppyseed, 
Appearance-red, hazy, tan foam, 
Taste-medium sourness, lightly bitter, 
Palate-medium body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish, 
Overall-ver good

Really impressed...A nice fruitiness and lace on the nose and appearance. Metallic and fruity and a bit of floral lead to a pretty clean cut mid taste, and then it disappears (in a good way). Love it.

Rubinowa barwa, piana redukuje się do obrączki.
Przyjemna i umiarkowanie intensywna mieszanka nut świeżego soku z wiśni i stajennych: lekko skisłe siano, klepisko, spocony koń. 
W smaku piwo jest mocno kwaśne, ale pozbawione nut octowych. Mocne wysycenie dodatkowo podszczypuje język. Wiśnie, podrasowane są cierpkim posmakiem pestek lub drewna. W tle pojawiają się nuty dzikie w postaci siana. Finisz jest wytrawny, z niską, pestkową goryczką.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet Aker Brygge. Mahogany brown color, beige head. Cherry nose, oak, sour candy, brown sugar, cherry pits. Sweet and sour taste, red berries, tart, brown sugar, floral, light malty and vinous notes, hint of dried fruit, moderate acidity. Rich, complex, smooth and balanced. Medium body, average carbonation, oily texture.

Pour brown with a touch of red, bordering on copper. Nice lasting head. Good lacing. Clear cheery aroma, a bit of caramel, sour notes, some funky, woody, almost like bourbon, and flowers. Very dry flavor. Good tartness, not excessive. Lemony finish with some nuttiness fro the cherries. Touch of vinegar. Nice and refreshing.

Pours ruby red with small head. Aroma: nice wild yeast aroma coupled with sour red fruit aroma. A touch of marzipan. Taste: nicely sour, but perfectly balanced with the body. Again nice red fruit, a touch of bacteria. Very balanced, nicely drinkable.
Bottle from Beer Gonzo, Coventry. Hazy red to brown colour with an off white head. Aroma red berry sour, slight malt very fruity. Taste light sweet to mid sour with a mid sweet and sour finish.

375 corked bottle served in a Brewdog chalice glass. Purchased at La Mise En Bière - Lausanne.
A: Pours a very dark amber cloudy color forming a medium yellow and creamy head with good retention that leaves a lot of soapy lacings in the glass.
S: Nose is very fruity, sour and metallic. Flowery. Strong notes of cherry and wood. Notes of leather and earth. Apple vinegar. Grassy hops. Caramel malts backbone. 
T: Slightly sweet upfront. Again very fruity. Strong notes of cherry and apple. Apple vinegar. Taste becomes quickly dry and acid but not overwhelming. Smooth. Good sweet-sour balance. Hints of oak and metal. Light hoppy bitterness. 
M: Light body. Medium carbonation. Cherry and oak in the aftertaste. 
O: Excellent drinkability. Reminds a Flanders Red. Delicate and flowery. Masterpiece.
Sample at SBWF. Pours orange with white head. Fresh aroma with notes of yeast and herbs. Really sour taste and finish.

Draft at armsby abbey. Pours wine dark red with a khaki head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Lovely cherry notes on the nose along with some oakiness. Lovely cherry tartness on the tongue. Finish lingers a bit. Nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark body with a medium beige head. Sour fruity aroma. Very nice sour taste with a wide fruity palate.

Draught sample at SBWF.
Pours hazy orange, offwhit head.
Aroma of poppy, vanilla, sour feel.
Taste sour peach, lambic, oranic feel, sweet.

12.7 oz bottle at home. No BB date. dark brown color, medium big off-white head. smells of wood, marzipan, cherry notes, light poppy seed, bit citric, coconut, light vinous notes, light funk. very lovely smell. medium body, medium carbonation, soft mouthfeel. tastes of cherry, vinous, some wood, light poppy seed (i guess) which gives a very soft and well-rounded taste, lightly sour, bit acidic, marzipan, bit nutty, light green apples, lightly vinegarish. finishes lightly sour with vinous notes, light vinegar, some barrel and cherry notes. very nice one, smell is very very nice, taste is a touch to vinegarish / bit too much carbonation, overall very lovely beer though.

Bottle sample at Sbwf. 
Pours red brown. 
Tart taste of red berries and poppy seeds.

Draught @ Himmeriget. Hazy reddish brown with a beige head. Cherry aroma with tart barnyard notes. A little berry sweetness with a solid amount of tart notes and a dry and very nice bitter finish. Excellent beer.
Lovely sourishberry like kick, overripe fruitiness aduga cookie poppy, some drying wood impact. Light sweetness, light sourness. Well balanced but nothing too fancy to cost this madness
Red with a white head - Sour aroma with some fruity hints and olso hints of vinegar - sour malt body with some fruity and berry notes - The sour flavour goes into a long finish - This was real good

On tap at Harrys Hofbrau in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is initially tart, underripe fruit but warms to some funky, musty oak notes. Taste is oaky, dry, tart and musty cherries. Very funky / mineral / oaky component. Really enjoyed how funky this was but was hoping for a touch more fruit sweetness.
Vraiment excellente! vinaigre balsamique équilibre le sucre, on ne goute pas le pavot!

Bottle at home. Hazy dark ruby with a thin beige head. Complex notes of cherries, wild funk, mould, caramel, vanilla, oak barrel, minerals and subtle sulphur. Medium tartness, slight saltiness and a low amount of sweetness. With high carbonation and a smooth, oily texture, it makes for a refreshing drink.

Bottle thanks to Kai. Pours hazy dark reddish brown with a small brown head. Aromas of vanilla, dark fruits, red berries, balsamico. Taste is vinegary, lactic, berries, vanilla, balsamico, dark fruits.

A corked 0.375l bottle from Ølbutikken. Had to struggle a bit to get the cork out of this, but when I did, it pours a deep dark dark amber colored thing, really cloudy and it has a wonderful looking fluffy everlasting dark beige top that is leaving nice lacing down the sides of the glass. Lovely tart nose, lots of berries and a soft velvety red vine vinegar. Also small notes of sour lime zest, wood, some mild form of sesame oil, sour raspberries and sour cherries? The aroma is lovely complex. Oh, its even more sour the the aroma led me to believe. Somewhat thin on the mouthfeel with a just above average carbonation level. Lots of sour berries here, watered down lime zest, acidic not ripe green gooseberries and yeah, red softly sour cherries. Its really delicate this lille thing! Cant remember that Ive had something quite like this before really. Tasty and so refreshing! Imagine having something like this widely available... 09.05.2013
Aroma of light funk, rose, light wine vinegar. Taste is light sour, dry. Light acidic flavor, rose, wine, barrel.
Dont understand the hype. Other - Belgian - breweries produce the same type of beer with better results. Fairly flat, not very tart...

Pours murky reddish brown, tan / brown head. Aroma is cherries, lacto, oak, malt, raspberry, cedar. Flavor is tart cherries, malt, light vinegar, wood. Medium body, med sour, cherries and dark fruits. Nice flanders
Bottle from trade. Nice brown red appearance. Aroma has nice tartness with toasted poppy. Taste is tart cherry up front, poppy seed in the middle, nice finish. Very complex and delicious.

Sampled on draft at 3R6P this beer poured a murky dark brown color with a large creamy red-beige head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was strong chalk, pez and a medicinal presence with band aid. The flavor was very tart and sour yet dry with pez, chalk, perfume, brett and a medicinal presence. Long finish. Medium body. Not my style.

Tasted from bottle. Pours dark ruby red, hazy with off white head. Aroma is sour funk with cherries. Taste is heavily sour. Big time tartness. Flavors of cherries, dark fruits, Belgian yeast and funk. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours murky brown with a reddish hue and medium light brown/khaki head with excellent retention. AROMA: tart cherries, sweet, woody, herbal, minerals, vanilla, citrus, toasted poppy, earthy, yeast esters, barnyard funk, sulfur, spices, sour berries, faint chocolate (?), malty, dark stone fruit and leaves. TASTE: malty, tart sweet cherries, minerals, lightly oaked, spices, phenolic, sour, earthy, leaves, herbs, blackberries, tannins, caramel, vanilla and bready. AFTER TASTE: tart dark cherries, malty, spiced, earthy and tannins with a sharp sour complex finish.

hazy brown colour with reddish notes, moderate sized beige head; aroma of wood, tannins, tart notes, unripe fruits, chardonnay and acetone notes; taste of balsamic vinegar, dry white wine, woody notes, (unripe) fruitiness, bitterish sour cherry and hints of acetone, as well as something which reminds me to marzepan - the sourish/acidic character does not dominate fully the taste and the acetone note is also in the background compared to other sour red beers, which makes it one of the best beers of the category - at least for me :-)

375 mL bottle shared with ebone1988. Got this one in a trade a while back. The pour is a darker brown with hints of red throughout the glass. There is a light bone colored head that falls to a thicker collar and thin film. The aroma is great. There is a bright sour cherry right up front. There is a great sour character to this one that is well received. There is a light malt and a hint of oak to go with the cherry. The fruits are nice and complex. There is a bit of funky barnyard on the back that ties it together nicely. The flavor is more sour cherry. There is a little more oak presence with a hint of vanilla. The barnyard funk really carries through with a hint of spiciness. I really like the sour control and the light complex additions. This one is great. The mouth feel is excellent with brighter carbonation. The aftertaste is sour cherry and a wonderful lingering oak. Its very good. Im a fan of this one.

Bottle shared with koleminer20. Aroma is wonderful, wine barrel, cherries, balsamic, tart, everything youd want in a sour red. Appearance is red brown, hazy, light broken head. Taste is wine, barrel, tannins, cherries, tart, dry, a nice dessert spice, incredible. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, crisp carbonation, tannin aftertaste, everything youd want from a sour red. Overall, this is incredible.

Tap at industry. This is a darker brew. Looks like iced tea. Smell is quite appealingly tart. Oh my, the taste is just as scrumptious. Little bit of hop bite but this is simply one good tasting tart beer, yummy. Very yummy. Oh so nice, really liked this one. I need another!
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 375ml corked bottle. Sour cherry aroma with notes of vinegar funkiness as well as a hint of wood. Pours caramel brown with a ruby tinge and thin tan head with decent retention and some lacing. Starts with tart cherry flavor up front with slight vinegary nuisances. Finishes like a dry red wine that clings to palate after each sip with a bit of oak flavor as well. Nice sour that's not overpowering.

Interesting. Its got a lot of tart, sour aroma at first, but the taste is not all that intense. Theres some cherry and a bit of barnyard Brett, but other than that its surprisingly fleeting. Less substantial than I was expecting.
Thick, yeasty body of sour red cherry and sandalwood/ oak nuances. Finish is long and refined.

W aromacie początkowo wanilia, karmel i... mak! Wręcz makowiec! Po czasie dochodzą czerwone owoce, kwasek, aromat nieco słabnie z czasem, ale pierwsze wrażenie jest piorunujące! W smaku raczej wytrawne, choć z wyraźnymi makowymi reminescencjami, lekka wiśnia, mocniejszy karmel, wyraźna kwaskowość, lecz nie kwaśność. Troszeczkę zbyt biedny posmak, minimalnie więcej goryczki ładnie domknęłoby kompozycję, aczkolwiek trunek już jest szlachetny i bardzo smaczny!

A: Red/brown with a big head that leaves a thin lacing on the glass. N: vinegar, bitter orange, kumquat, vanilla, oak, dates, cherry, raisins T: Strawberry, cherry, vanilla. O: Bitter, sweet and tart. Not great flavours in my opinion. Alright though.

Märkrödfärg med naturlig bubblig ganska vit krona, dofter blandade av enkel mörk kola /sirap fatlagrad, tillsammans med surighet & rödvinston. Syrlig, sursmak med tanniner blandad med körsbär, ek & kola. surig, gammel torkadefruktigt eftersmak

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Brown colour with tan head. Fruity, cherry, nut aroma. Sweet, sour, fruity, cherry, wood taste. Medium body.
Bottle at home. Pours hazy brown, nose is funky, oak, light fruit, taste is dry, light funk, oak, vinegar.

12.7 oz. bottle that I happily picked up a while back at Yankee Spirits in Attleboro, MA. Pours a deep but translucent red with a somewhat fizzy white head that lasted through the first two sips and left spotty lace. Very pleasant aroma of cherries, oak, malt, and some mild red wine vinegar. The flavor is sour with cherry and a bit of oak. Bright on the palate with very mild bitterness at the finish. Light-medium bodied. Very nice.

Bottle from Firma Bier. Chestnut brown with thin head. Smell seeds, cinnamon, leather. Mild sour, spacious flavor filled with herbs, poppyseed, cardemom, cumin. Sherry-like, very flowery, strawberry. Some dough, breadiness. Fermented cherry juice. Very pleasant and no unwanted flavors. Supple mouthfeel, very dry.

Bottle shared thanks to Sjogro. Hazy reddish brown with big off white head. Quite some spices (cardamom, cumin), lactic notes, flowery, sour cherries, funk, sherry, overripe strawberries, brown bread. Medium sour with light sweetness and light spicy bitterness in the finish. Medium bodied with slight creamy feel and quite some carbonation. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours red, cloudy, with whitish head that quickly disappears. Aroma of cherries with lots of sourness, distinct barrel notes. Taste is distinctly sour with astringent aftertaste of tannins and cherry stones.

375ml bottle - shared by martjoobolut - thanks!
Opened with a big pop, but I was very careful to ensure it didnt gush. Pours a hazy red, with a quite fizzy, but also pleasantly persistent off-white head. Pleasant sweet aroma, some cherry, some childrens sweeties. Later a bit of coconut, but not in an oily (sorachi ace) way. Much less sweet taste. Crisp palate, nice level of acidity, and crisp carbonation too, I did prefer it after a bit of swirling. Nicely woody body, black cherry and cherry stones, and again that strange hint of coconut. Very refreshing, perfect balance of fruitiness and sourness. Excellent sour fruit beer.

Bottle. Pours redish brown with beige head. The small head stays. Aroma is sweet, sour, oak, red fruits, slight vanilla. Flavor is sour and dry, red fruits, oak. Finish is dry and some oak. Carbonation is high. Overall: very good

Hazy brown beer, big fluffy tan head. Nose is fruity sourness, sweet, malty notes, yeast. Flavor is tart and fruity, cherries, wood, berries. Dry and acidic finish with a syrupy edge, its not overpowering though. Lingering berry tartness and dryness. Very nice.

On tap at Caliente. Pours a murky brownish red with a slight light tan head. Aromas of vinegar, cherry, mineral water, nutty. Taste is light sour, with a clean finish. Slightly dry. Medium light body. Pretty good but I feel the newer sours har surpassed it.
Backlog. Murky brown/deep red. Small head. Aroma is funk, oak, vinegar, fermented cherries. Complex with a nice balanced sour finish.

Deep Amber red and tint of brown pour with nice fluffy white head and great lacing. Smell of sour cherries raspberries and some plums and raisins. Taste of prickly tart and fruits all over of cherries raspberry and stone fruit. Some wine and brandy character in mouthfeel. Very complex and yummy brew.

Bottle shared with jheath99. Pours cloudy dark amber with a little white head. Aroma of berries, wood, tart poppies. Tastes of poppies, berries and a definite sour taste. But its not overly sour. Heavy bodied and medium carbonation. Im not a fan of fruity or sour beers, but I really enjoyed this one. Well done Lost Abbey. Youve converted this beer drinker.
Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy amber with a reddish tint and a thin ring of off white head. Taste and aroma of tart, berries, and wood, with nice carbonation.

37.5cl bottle from Beers of Europe. Backlog rating. It pours a dark ruby brown color with small pinkish head. Aroma is intense tart cherries vinegar esters and red wine. Taste is acidic with notes of tart cherries raspberries vinegar. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, very nice

Really getting into sours so I am fortunate to be able to go here. Pours reddish cloudy and light carbonation. Obviously the fruits dominated with some wine character. Cherries raspberries sme peach and sme wood notes. Fantastic beer.

This sour gem has my vote for all time favorite sour beer. Very nice color,very strong cherry notes, I would recommend to anyone who hasnt tried it yet if you can find it...I havent been able to find a bottle of this stuff in a few years!

Draft. Muddy light brown. Im giving it the benefit of the doubt from being served poorly. Spotty white head. Yeast/brett, oak, and cherry lead the parade. Semi dry. Acidic. A medium to high, complex sourness. Tart. Intense, yet refined. Not perfect, but very very good.

37,5cl bottle at home. Almost clear, dark copper colour, offwhite foamy head that leaves a nice lacing. Fruity and earthy, funky nose and taste with sour cherries, green apples, vinegar, roasted malts with light caramel, iron-y. Clean and dry. Lively carbonation, medium body, soft mouthfeel. I like the Belgian Flemish browns better.

Awesome sour, garnet pour with quick fading white head. Aroma of all kinds of delicious fruits. Tart and sour and some funk. It had some vinegar in it that was quite enjoyable believe it or not. Just slight but added to acidity. Great great!!!

A reddish brown, a light beige head is very big and slowly growing. Aroma is great, cherries, raspberries, some sourness of vinegar, hint of chocolate. Taste is strongly sour, cherries, cherrie stones, some iron, low sweetness. Medium bodied, fresh carbonatin, slightly sticky as usual. The great and balanced beer, enjoyable.

375 ml bottle from Ammersin Centerstore, Brunn/Gebirge.
Dark copper body, with a medium, fizzy, dissipating, slightly pink head.
Wonderful, complex aroma of oak, wine, vanilla, berries, cherries, funk, some ripe fruits.
Taste is also delicious, indeed with poppy seed, funk, oak, wine, vanilla, sour berries and cherries, apples, overripe fruits, some vinegar.
Medium mouthfeel, with a fizzy carbonation.
Finishes smooth, sour, dry, a bit funky, with oak and fruit notes.

Clearly the best Sour Red/Brown Ive had so far, offering everything great from this style, but with the unique twist of the poppy seeds that works really well. Extra point for the low ABV compared to other world class beers of this style. Amazing stuff!

3300th review! 375 ml bottle into tulip glass, 2015 vintage bottling. Pours slightly hazy deep ruby red color with a 2 finger fairly dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty foamy lacing clings around the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big sour black cherry, cranberry, green apple, lemon, red grape, cider vinegar, caramel, toasted oak, hay, straw, peppercorn, musty funk, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Incredible aromas with awesome complexity and balance of sour cherry, fruity/funky/spicy yeast, dark malt, and oak barrel notes; with great strength. Taste of big sour black cherry, cranberry, green apple, lemon, red grape, cider vinegar, caramel, toasted oak, hay, straw, peppercorn, musty funk, herbal, and yeast earthiness. Good amount of fruity/acidic tartness and yeast spiciness on the finish; with lingering notes of black cherry, cranberry, green apple, lemon, red grape, cider vinegar, caramel, toasted oak, hay, straw, peppercorn, musty funk, herbal, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Incredible complexity and balance of sour cherry, fruity/funky/spicy yeast, dark malt, and oak barrel flavors; with an pretty much perfect malt/acidity balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. High carbonation and medium bodied; with a very smooth, crisp, and moderately acidic mouthfeel that is incredible. Alcohol is very well hidden with zero warming present after the finish as expected of 5%. Overall this is a world class Flanders red ale style. All around fantastic complexity and balance of sour cherry, fruity/funky/spicy yeast, dark malt, and oak barrel flavors; and very smooth and crisp to drink with the balanced acidity. An insanely amazing offering.

Reddish brown pour small off white head. True not for faint of heart. Molasses, tartness Belgian like phenols, candi sugar and more citric tartness. Perfectly well balanced. Malty mouthfeel and the acid tartness drys it right out. Perfect.

Big tart cherry up front and in the aroma. Raw oak complements well and gives the impression of sweetness. Quite tart. Funk that blends into the cherry. Had this after a JP, and this is more sour (acetic) and about equally funky, but it also has more depth and sweetness from the fruit and oak. Lovely sweet cherry oak aftertaste. A real puckerer. Surprising head.

Bottle. One of those Lost Abbey sours that just kills. Felt bad about the $17 price tag for a small bottle but I already wish I had picked up more. Tart, fruit, funk... Balanced and wonderful. A great Flanders Red... Even a "holy shit" beer. What we do it for, sour freaks....

Cherry red with brown highlights and a light brown foam. Cherry and oak aromas with a spritz of grape must. Tart, sour, sweet flavors of fruit and wood balance well without leaving that overpowering pucker found in some beers. Its actually better when served at cellar temps.

Bottle. Pours hazy brown with a red hue, with a creamy, off white head. Aroma is sweet fruity, with cherries and balsamic vinegar, as well as nuts, dates, tannins, leather and oak barrels. Medium body, with soft to no carbonation. Flavour is sweet fruity malts, with balsamic vinegar, cherries, forest berries and tannins, as well as nice oaken barrels.

12.7 oz bottle, about 4 years old. Pours dark ruby amber with a fizzy light tan head that retains well and leaves some lacing.

The aroma is sweet cherries with some vinegary tartness and some woodiness.

The flavor is sweet and very tart sour cherry with some acidic wood notes in the background. The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with low carbonation that is a little prickly.

Overall, a very nice sour.

37,5cl bottle shared by Arve_Christian - thanks a lot! Pours hazy brownish with an off-white head. Fruity and slightly funky aroma with lots of cherries, hints of balsamic vinegar and citrus. Sour, acidic, fruity and simply delicious! Lovely stuff!

On bottle from Vinmonopolet Vika, amber color- good foam. High aroma intensity; stable, cherries and some autumn leaves. Medium body & medium high complexity. Good sourness- some bitterness. Very enjoyable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle purchased at the source. Drank it at a park with a sandwich from Uncle Henry's Deli. Cork popped off when the cage was removed. Poured a slightly hazy pink with a huge foamy head. Aroma was berries - raspberries and strawberries. Mildly tart with some sweetness. Really nice and refreshing.

May 4th, 2013 - Losy Abbeys Amerosa is a hard act to follow, but the Red Poppy steps up proudly. Like the previous brew, its got a deep, crimson glow, though more transparent and with a thinner head. My sample glasss head has already deflated, letting off a wonderful smell. Its sour and very similar to La Folie, but smoother, oilier, sleeker and even a little smug. The oily touch resembles the smell of cashew butter, and the tangy sweetness brings in the goopy sweet of agave syrup and the unique smell of tequila. A sweet, smooth succulent palate embraces the drinker. While low and dense, it is also quenching, with a barrel aged sourness and a custard richness. In many ways it is like a cream ale, but then on another sip it tastes like a beer-iified version of dulce de leech or sweeten condensed beer. As for the rest of my notes, they dribble off the page as my brain shifted from an analytical mode to an appreciative one, where I write "new favorite Lost Abbey beer?" Enough said.

Vintage 2013 on draught at Publick House, 3/20/14 and bottle, drunk 3/29/14In both, the appearance is a dark, ruby/black cherry tinted brown beer with a smattering of beige head that shows poor retention. Good clarity.Definite sharp acetic tones produce some near acetone-like notes and certainly lend an aggressive feel to the nose. Oak character contributes tannins and plenty of vanilla and dry black pepper-like phenols. Cherries just seem to be left as an essence here, much like the Framboise, being completely attenuated. With warming and breathing, more lactic notes emerge, softening things somewhat. Traces of toffee and caramel add some pleasant sweet notes to all of this heavily dry, tart nose. Love the relatively low alcohol content though, and none of it shows through.Intensely sour and dry in the mouth. Phew, this is a lot of barrel tannin, acetic acid and very sharp malic acids from the cherries. The draught version hadnt been as far attenuated as the bottle, still having more soft malt notes to smooth out some of this intense acidity. I like the flavors going on, for the most part, but there isnt enough malt body or sweetness to balance this intensely sharp acetone-like character that lingers on the finish. I do like that the sourness/tartness is not really cherry-driven, however. Not just a glass of cherry juice. Very phenolic, dry and just a bit too unbalanced on the sour side, even for a sour addict such as myself.Interestingly enough, the draught version was not as bright and the sediment still in solution helped balance some of the sharpness/heavy tannin, and sure enough, pouring a little bit of sediment from the bottom of the bottle actually helped dull the sharpness without really comprimising the flavor. Good and still very drinkable on account of the dryness and low alcohol but Ive got to imagine this hasnt been their best vintage.

Bottle. I really enjoyed this one. Pours clear ruby with some floaties and a large fizzy tan head that dissipates with nice lacing. Aroma is sour cherry, funk, oak, grapes. Flavor is the same, quite oaky actually, but without much woody tannic astringence. Vinous with medium tartness and just a tough of funk. Finish is quite dry. Medium body, high carbonation, but not distracting from the overall experience.
Pours a dirty, dark red, white foam. complex smell of.. A forret in vinegar, but nice. A mild fruity sour ale, somehow salty, lovly.

Sampled at GABF 2013. A great fruity sour with tart cherries, oak and wine. Smooth and complex flavor.
Bottle pours a dark hazy red with an off white tan head. Sour cherry aroma. Tart cherry and grape skin taste.

Via trade with LostHops287.  The aroma is cherries, sour, vinegar, wood. The appearance is slightly hazy red/brown, thin off-white head. The flavor is tart cherry, vinegar, sweet and sour at the same time. The finish is sour, acid, cherries, wood. Medium in body. Very good.
A bottle pour a few weeks back. My first sour brown and let me tell you, this beer is something! Holy cherries! I really like gulping down this fine liquid. My only gripe, I wish it came in a bomber!

375 mL bottle. Acquired in a trade with tom10101 - Merci tommy. The hardest part of drinking this beer was getting the cork out. It is an incredibly complex and flavourful beer. Ther cherries, the sour, the malt vinegar, and the oak all come together in an incredible way. Hard to believe that this is only 5.0%. Best sour brown Ive tried, hands down.

Bottle. Thin light tan head, deep dark brown with some ruby highlights. Balsamic vinegar, rich ripe dark cherry, and some lacto sour and wood in the aroma. Flavor is much more sour and bright than the aroma lets on, with tart dark cherry, woodiness, sourness, and a very dry tart finish. Lighter body with nice bright carbonation.

On tap @ Lost Abbey. Pours hazy reddish brown with a minimal khaki head. Smells of cherries, lots of cherries, funky fruit, beard, hay sweet malts and a little floral. Taste is sour cherries, acidic fruit, light bread, red wine vinegar and oak. Medium to full body with little carbonation.

375 ml bottle. Pours a ruby-brown color with a small fizzy head that fades quickly. Aroma is dominated by sour cherry funk, maybe a touch of oak too. Taste is very acidic, sour cherries with moderate funk and some oakiness. Long tart finish. As with most sours, Im not impressed. I did enjoy it but not worth anything close to the price I paid.

Bottle. Pours cloudy red/brown-ish with a lacy beige head. Aroma is Cherries, sour, funk, bread, barnyard, some malts, floral and raisin. Taste is medium sour and light sweet. Absolutely fantastic mouthfeel. Long sour finish.

2011 Vintage. Aroma is fairly fruity with a balanced malt backbone. Lots of cherry, cassis and raspberry notes. Background malt has hints of caramel and faint chocolate. Faint toasted bread character. Light acidity.Pours a slightly cloudy brown with ruby highlights and a moderately thick tan head that slowly buy steadily recedes. Moderate lacing and no legs. Flavor is instantly tart with balanced fruit and malt. Lots of berries and tart cherries. Malt balances the acidity and fruit well and adds some light caramel and toasted bread notes. Hints of chocolate as well. Faint barrel notes but they play third string to the fruit and malt.Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium high carbonation. Low acidic astringency and low alcohol warmth. A bit sticky. Overall a very nice beer; I would go so far as to say the best American Flemish sour I have had. The price point is steep but the quality is high. Such nice fruit notes with well balanced malt. I think perhaps there could be more barrel character but that is my one knock on this beer. As it warms the barrel notes become more noticeable bit still very light.

2012 Bottle ~1 year old. Pours clear brown with a ruby hue and fizzy diminishing head after a powerful cork pop.. The aroma is huge and intense balsamic and cider acetic, barnyard funk; malt sour and red wine notes. From cork pop and from a distance there is a wild cooked mushroom hint. Thats weird but not strong or bad. The flavor is very woody, acetic sour, tart and tannic both at the start and finish, cherries macerated in balsamic, Brett. The texture is watery, woody, and yeasty in the end. This thing is very intense and complex. I cant tell if it is about to go bad or is really almost untamed and will settle in nicely. Its almost too much at points except I could live in the aroma.
Mahoganybrun öl med beige skum. Doft av trä, vanilj, kola och körsbär. Samma återkommer i smaken tillsammans med en lätt syrlighet och efterbeska.

Small bottle kindly shared by my beer pal, Ole Anders. Mahogany clear body with a light brown head. Pickled vanilla, cherries and barrel notes on the nose and more fudge as it heats. Sour cherries with a nice almond bitterness. Medium to full bodied and smooth to drink. Fantastic.

Pours a bubbly deep ruby-brown color with a finger width head. A fruity cherry aroma with a good amount of funk. taste is a beautiful biting tart flavor with a trace of the barrel aging mixed in. A carbonated mouthfeel and this beer rises above many others. Love it.

From notes.  First reviewed 7/25/2011.  Poured from a 375 mL bottle into a tulip. 2010 Vintage. Thanks to readbaron for opening this with me.

This pours a hazy medium dark brown with a murky beet red tint that is more obvious at the edges. Although I started the pour gently, it took an aggressive pour right into the center of the glass to populate a foamy tan head with small but visible bubbles. The head fades at its leisure, eventually leaving a ring around the edge of the glass and a few spots of lace down the side.

The aroma is the strength of this beer. Although for a Flanders Red Ale I would normally expect the aroma and flavor to be quite similar, the nose on this is actually more complex than the flavor. Obvious tart cherries are the first entrant into my olfactory system, but as I adjust I sense some oak, balsamic vinegar, and a bit of cinnamon. With a few swirls of the glass, a vibrant funk rises into my nostrils, adding further complexity.

A blast of tart cherries assaults my tongue up front with just a touch of balsamic sweetness, more of a pure sour flavor than I am used to in a Flanders Red. Once my palate acquaints itself with the flavor, I get nuances of oak and red wine in the middle, but the flavor pretty much has one gear -- sour and cherry. This bottle has a year on it already, which I imagine has led to it being more sour than when it was fresh, and I cant help but wonder if it would get better with even more time to develop. 

The tartness up front causes my mouth to salivate profusely right away. There is no doubt that this has a strong vinegar character and a fairly acidic feel. Lots of tannins present at the end. The body is actually a bit lighter than I would expect from a beer of this style, with the carbonation falling into the abyss somewhere between creamy and crisp. A bit of creamy, relaxed carbonation would suit this a bit better. 

When the bottle was opened I was pleasantly surprised by the depth of the aroma, only to be let down a little bit by the flavor. It was good, but nothing about this truly differentiated itself from other beers in the style. Why spend the effort to track this down and pay premium money for this when there are better options that are both cheaper and more readily available?

The nose is really stellar, with a caramel maltiness that melds into a sour cherry aroma with hints of coconut, chocolate malt, vanilla, lemon acidity, and just a touch of balsamic vinegar and barnyard funk.  The flavor is quite nice, but doesnt quite live up to the nose, with more sour lemon and cherry, the caramel and chocolate malt dialed way back, but still the very nice touches of vanilla, coconut, barnyard and balsamic.  The body is light with a sticky tannic texture, light carbonation, and a very long finish that includes the sour notes, caramel and chocolate malt, but the oaky vanilla and coconut notes really shine through on the finish.
The only bad thing was that I did not age this beer as long as I wanted.  The red cherries in oak barrels are a match for tasting curious.  The hues of red meet the eye and then overwhelm the soul.
12.7 oz bottle sharred by me. Mild sour tartness and fruit juice.  Not the top that it is rated, but still good

Bottle @ Too many Geuzes - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012 - Day 1. DArk reddish brown color (not that appealing), with a nice beige head that lasts. Intense sweet fruity malty aroma, cherries ,oak, caramel a little funkiness. Tastes funkier than the smell suggests. Again string sweet malt base, raisins, wood, cherries, some lemon sourness. Lovely
Bottle @ fonefan tasting. Hazy reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, cherries and oak. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 270112

Aroma:kirsebær vinøs tømmer Ud.:kobberrød uklar Skum:hvidt   E.smag:sød lidt sur moderat til meget bitter lid Krop:medium For.:tør Brus:blød  
27/1-12 @f1

Cloudy light brown color with thin white head. Musty oaky aroma with a hint of whisky. Sour tart palate with subtle fruit flavor. Hard to tell its cherry with any certainty. Initial taste reminds me of a Belgian lambic. Finish has of mellow bourbon flavor with notes of Vanilla To find an American sour is rare and bourbon barrel though rising in poPularity is -still relatively rare but to find a barrel aged sour (two of my favorites) is a beer lovers holy grail.

Bottle. Pours dark red/ruby with a good off-white head, some retention, no lace. Aroma of cherries, oak, brown sugar, funk. Taste is tart, sour, cherries, oak, vinegar, with a slight sweetness. Palate is soft, slick, high carbonation. Very nice, but when opened with supplication did not compare.
Bottle from Nugget. Aroma and flavor of tart cherries, light brown sugar, and was refreshingly dry. Wonderfully made beer, but I also dont get the pricetag. Great beer.

Bottle. Pours a nice dark ruby red color with a beige head. Aroma is sour with lots of cherries, balsamic vinegar, brown sugar, dark fruits, caramel and some red apple and subtle funk. Flavor follows the nose with lots of sour cherries, balsamic vinegar, subtle funk, oak, dark fruits, caramel, brown sugar and red apple notes. The body is medium with a dry mouthfeel. Overall a really nice American Sour!

Poured into tulip, finger of off white head. Sediment is at the bottom. Smell is tart and balanced. Taste is strong cherry. Sour, almost bitter. Candied, almost. Very smooth and balanced. Sits on the tongue quite well. Very well done, but I dont think its worth the price tag.

Tap/Growler from the 2011 RBWG and a 2 yr old bottle-pours dark red with a fizzy off-white head.  nose is different between the two-the tap had more vinegar/bright lactic sourness whereas the bottle aged version has more of a cherry currant note to it.  both were great noses.  flavors are very sour-lots of cherrries, toasted wood (oak), vineous, vinegar, plums, with tons of puckering sweetness on the finish.  This is a very sour beer if you ask me.  With that said, its very tasty and is good fresh or aged.  Body is lite and crisp with ample carbonation.  i think the fresh tap version was a bit more sour than this 2 yr old bottle.  regardless, a very solid american example of this style.

Still fairly new to the sour/wild ale, but Im rapidly starting to appreciate them. This is more like a wine than a beer. Pours a dark copper-brown with very thick, foamy head. Cherry-fruit aroma. Flavor is sour with a touch of cherry. Theres even a remote hint of some sweetness in there. Very interesting and worth a try to sip and savor.

Pours deep red and almost black. Nose is lots of Brett funk, lactic sourness, acetic acid, and some malts.  The flavor lends complex notes of funk, wood, cherries, other fruits, leather, vinegar. Puckering, and spritzy. Nice fruit and acid combination. Nice.

Amazing at turkey day dinner. Pours a murky brown red with minimal head. Lacing is excellent smells like fresh cherries. So ripe and delicious the sour level is huge and balanced. One of my all time favorites from la. The levels of sourness is amazing I think lost abbey hAs a winner with this one.

375 ml caged and corked bottle.  Served in a snifter, the beer pours a murky brown color with some tints of red, and about a half inch light tan head.  Head retention was OK, and there isnt much lacing left on the glass.  Aroma is mostly tart, the brew smells like tart cherries, oak, vinegar, and some funk.  The taste is similar to the aroma, but theres also some red grapes noticeable too.  Theres also a long lasting tart finish.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, and it has high but soft carbonation which eases up some as the beer warms.  I think this is a pretty good overall brew, its easy to drink and quite enjoyable.  But because of the high price ($16.99 a bottle), its going to be a very long time before I consider buying it again.

It seems like a great idea, and was technically well-done.  It was so sour, I couldnt make it through it- it hit the pipes.  None of my overall points were for the taste.  I like the other Lost Abbey beers that I have had, but not this one.

Bottle. Pours a dark slightly murky brown with reddish tinges down the side of the glass. Small light tan coloured head. Flavours of dark sour cherries, malt vinegar and acetone. Some wood coming through in the back ground. Flavours are dominated by sour cherries with a touch of vinegar. Nice beer

Bottle (2009 vintage). Muddy reddish brown pour, with a bit of white head (head, really! on a LA beer! I know!). Aroma of vinegar, quite acetic, some cherries, pretty unilateral. Taste is sooo sour, tastes like biting into a lemon, slightly fruity but ridiculously sour.  Palate is very lightly carbonated but carbonated non the less. Body is light and the finish is obviously very dry, this stuff is sucking saliva out of my glands. I kind of like it, even though it is barely drinkable. Way too harsh.

[10/3/11] Bottle at Mikkeller Bar in Copenhagen. Dark cloudy red with a pinkish head. Somewhat funky aroma of oak, cherries and notes of malt. Sweet-sour flavor with oak, brett, lactic notes, cherries and a bit of malty notes. Rounded mouthfeel. Good stuff.

GABF 2011.  Murky dark rusty copper brown. Aroma of dank wood musty toffee, some sourness. Taste is really sour but mellows out halfway out to reveal oak, Chardonnay, sour yeast, perhaps a bit of nuttiness and toffee. Not my thing

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2012 Slightly tart aroma and still a bit sweet with cherry notes.  Murky brown in color.  Malt is fairly pronounced but with a slightly tart edge; like a sour cider with a bit of cherry.

murky brown/orange in colour some head and some  lace. at first it smells quite soapy but then it is all cherries, yeast or something woody, quite interesting. it is quite sour but not too tart, which is good. Has a real vitamin C kind of taste. very interesting...one of the better beers of this style that Ive had.

375ml bottle. Pours a dank brown/orange colour with a tan head. The bottle pulled the oddest slow gusher effect when opened - it just kept steadily spewing a little bit of foam. Funky sour cherry nose with a really oaky, vanilla note. The same is true of the palate but an almost savoury note is added. The finish is a little short but satisfyingly salivatingly sour.

Pours a cloudy medium to dark brown slight red hew with minimal head that lingers. Nose is oak, brown malt, sour and slight malt vinegar. First sip is sour cherries, vanilla & oak. Finish is pleasant with minimal lingering grapefruit. Very nice.

The bottle I received in trade was flat. It had a nice tart flavor of cherries and sweet fruits. A bit on the bready side. Not a big sour/wild ale fan but from what I am told by  those that are the 2010 vintage was nothing special.

2011 vintage from a bottle. Very nice lookign beer, brownish red in color with copious head and lacing. Very floral aroma to this one. Taste is very sour up front, cherries and funk come along for the ride. The tartness lingers on the tongue. Very good beer!

Bottle at Browuers. Sour, tart cherry, little oak, little ready funk. Cloudy reddish brown, ok head no lace. Sour Flavor lite body, lite creamy. Sour finish. Good sour goes down easy.  Alot of flavor for 5%
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a fizzy small tan head. Aroma was full and pungent with sour cherries, oak, a hint of apples and some light funk. Flavor was highly acidic with sour & tart cherries, caramel, mild funk and oak with a sour and dry finish.  An excellent sour ale

smells very wild, puckery sour smell, cherry but mainly soury smell. Tastes very sour, with a bitter hit, old wood with some cherry work for sure. very interesting, this beer is probably before my time on the beer, but i can totally understand why it would be a great beer. Would recommend for the serious beer drinker

2009 vintage, 375ml bottle. This one pours a dark, hazy crimson red color and topped by a small head of off white foam that settles quickly to a thin film and leaving drippy legging behind on the glass. The aroma is really nice and is based mostly in sour cherries, oak tannins, some lactic sourness, and leather. There is vinous red grape character along with a hint of funk in there as well. The flavor follows suit with the sour cherries, funk, and old wood taking center stage. The funk and sourness intensifies after each sip while the old oak and lactic character smooth things out a bit. Medium bodied and smooth with moderate carbonation that leads to a dry, sour finish. Not as intensely sour as I was hoping for or expecting from Lost Abbey, but still a really solid sour ale. Good stuff.

375 mL bottle from the brewery, served in a snifter at a tasting at Dans. Pours hazy brown with a moderate tan head. The head fades quickly to a thin remnant, leaving a small amount of lace. The nose is sour and dry with notes of cherries, oak and a touch of apples. The flavour is intensely sour up front, becoming slightly less so towards the end. There are notes of oak and cherries throughout. The finish is average in length, sour with huge cherries. On the palate, it is light-medium in body with a watery texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice sour cherry ale but the cherries are a little too dominant for my taste. 2011-07-09

Pours a murky reddish/light brown color with a bubbly white head, leaving behind little lacing. It smells very much like sour cherries. It also has a bit of a lemony zest to it as well. It tastes very much like the nose would suggest. Very tart, makes you pucker at first, but not overly tart that it cant be handled. Very good beer to drink and one you can drink a lot of with a 5.5%abv if you can drink a lot of sour beers. Overall a beer I wish I could have much more of.

375 ml bottle.
Pours cloudy red with medium head. Aroma is strong with sour cherries, some earthy notes and a bit citrus. Flavour is sour cherries, distant notes of honey and a bit of rasberries also. Very sour palate. Exciting and very good beer.
3375

37,5 cl bottle
Aroma is sour in an oud bruin way with oaky cherries. Flavour has very intensive sour cherries and oak. It contains some nice, sweet honey to balance the sourness. Lots of CO2 in the palate. Good sour ale even though I am not a big friend of this flemish bruin style.

375 ml bottle.
Pours a deep reddish brown colour with a small fizzy head. Aroma of very sour cherries and honey. Quite extreme flavour of strong, sour, stinging cherries, honey, toffee and smooth oak after a while. Some mild acidity as well. Dry, sour, ripe fruity finish where the cherries and oak really feel. One awesome sour ale which is oud bruin like.

Muddy caramel with light tan head / Bretty aged cherry and oak nose / Medium body, sour, lots of oak astringency, with good balance and long finish / Flavors of sour cherries, rotting apples, cedar, caramel, chocolate, old sweater, cinnamon, and more barnyard funk / A little too much new oak for me, but still a fine brew.

Cork and wire 12.7 oz bottle, slightly chilled. Pours murky reddish brown into a tulip glass (its a gusher, so be careful with this one). Lots of big brown fizzy head, robust sediment swirling. Nose is incredibly tart, with cherries, barnyard funk, hay, clean vinegar. First sip is almost bracingly sour, but then settles in to reveal wonderful cherry notes, more vinegar and spring-day earthiness. Clean, crisp finish, but with a pleasant sour lingering on the back of the throat. Top-notch sour ale.

Bottle.  Murky reddish brown pour with a huge off white head.  GUSHER..  Dark cherry, funk, barnyard, and wet leather aromas.  Tart cherries, acidic stone fruits, and supple caramel malt flavors.. A little over carbonated but still another gem from Tommy and the crew at LA.....

Pours murky caramel color with little head to speak of.  Aroma hit me as soon as I uncorked the bottle.  Sour apples, dark cherry pie filling, toffee, figs.  Good carbonation, medium think mouth feel.  Drinks like it looks.  Tastes of sour apples, dark cherries, bubble gum, some sweet fresh baked bread.  Sour fades, but the rest lasts.  Excellent.
Red-brown without head. Some cherries, big bodied and round acidity. Some almonds and fruity, slightly vinous. Very slight funk. Flavours are very well held together. Another great sour from LA.
Fantastic wild.  Aroma of oak and rich cherries and slight funk.  Taste is sour but balanced wonderfuly by the oak characteristics.  Notes of toasted caramel accent the cherries.
Pours light red colour , medium carbonation. Delicious fruity notes, cherry not overpowering. Taste of cola cubes. Sour. Very tasty.

On tap at Monks. Pours a full, deep maroon with medium beige head. Aroma is a full and balanced blend of sherry, red wine vinegar, and lemon; a nose of rich, tart, acetic loveliness. Flavor is a blend of peach, lemon, balsamic vinegar, and funk. Full of vinegar in the finish. Prickly mouthfeel with a splash of refreshing mineral water before the sherry and vinegar comes back. Really good sour.
Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Amber colour. Light malty and hoppy heavy sour arom. Light bitter very sour flavor. Average light bitter finish. Oily palate. Nice sour.

Deep red- brown pour with a beige head leaving heavy lace. Sour nose with some brown sugar spiciness. Medium body and fine, moderate carbonation Tart, cherries, strawberries, oak, lemon, caramel. Finish is dry and tart. Just about perfect.

Draught at eleven. Brown with a modest beige head. Light tart cherry and strong brett-lactic aroma. Huge lemony sourness with supporting tart cherry and an overall quite dry finish. Light toasty malt, but the sour character dominates. Not very fruit-frward on the whole, especially compared to their framboise. Light bodied and quite drinkable, though the sourness starts to wear on the palate toward the end of the glass. Good stuff.

Bottle at Brewdog Bar Aberdeen. It pours deep red-brown, with a thick long-lasting fluffy beige head. The nose is urine, wood, sour lemon, Granny Smith apple, candy floss and glazier cherry. The taste is tart cherry, raspberry, redcurrant, red grape, sour lemon, wood and light malt vinegar, with a very tangy, sour finish. It is warming, flavoursome and very well balanced. I am really impressed how drinkable this is. Awesome.
UPDATED: JAN 28, 2012 Bottle. Small head with short duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma and taste are very sour fruits, lots of brett, malt and hops. Rerated @ fonefan tasting. 8/3/9/4/18

12.7 oz bottle poured into tulip. Pours an amber tan color out of bottle with a lively beige frothy head...sits a dark brown color (cant see through) when in the glass. Aroma is very sour of course with the abundance of cherries. Oak, caramel, vanilla, and berries on the nose also. The taste is an amazing sour experience! Sweet cherries at the start and quickly gets more sour...flavors of cherries/berries mixed slightly mixed with oak. It sits on the palate pretty lightly, nicely fizzy and the finish stays around for the right amount of time before fading away. One of the best sours I have had so far...I bought it based on its reputation and it was well worth it. You need to try this if youre thinking about it...Id highly recommend it to the sour fans.

Pours very dark, brownish amber with a dense two finger head that reduces slowly to a spattered pancake. Defined sourness on the aroma. Medium nectar with creamy carbonation. Dry as a bone and sour like unripened stone fruit and cherries. This extreme ale is a well balanced brew and very stylish while not overpowering the user with alcohol.

Yeah, this pretty much tops the list for me as far as sours go.  An incredible amount of tart cherry in the aroma and flavor as well as lots of oak.  Highly acidic and finishes very dry. Lively and sharp carbonation. Overall, a great sour ale.  In avoiding sours for so long, I may have been missing out.

Bottle thanks to Bigmmartin.  Aroma is sour cherries and sweet malts.  I get notes of oak and a little bit of floralish notes.  Palate is light bodied with a nice carbonation level.  Flavor is sour and a little sweet at the same time.  Pretty good.

33cl bottle @ Brewdog Bar in Edinburgh. Pours a murky brown with no head. The nose has cider vinegar and a sweet woody note at the end. The taste is of apple sorbet, grapes and then a hint of caramel on the end. The palate is very lambic or even red ale - dry and sour all the way through, a very tight but rich texture and the sourness continues on the end. Overall, a nice interesting beer.
Tart, cedar, apple, nose. Cloudy brown, thick head, no retention, foamed out of the bottle. Sour currant, woody finish.

Fluffy beige head over fully hazed red-brown beer. Typical oud bruin nose with wood, lots of lactic acid, milk chocolate, sourish fruit, cherries. Wood, oak, dry, lactic acid, excellent! Fruity notes, but impossible to say whether cherries or other fruit, lipsmacking dry finish. Very refreshing, until the dryness takes over. Very good, no, excellent Vlaams oud bruin - top job from Tomme.  Big thanks to Ryan and Victor!

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2014 Pours redish brown with a beige head. Aroma of leather, vinegar, green apples. light tartness, sour grapes, oaky notes and some dark dried berries and sour berries. Taste of green sour apples, oak, sweet cherry, vinegar, tart, light balsamic notes, black currants, light stable, red wine and some light malty notes in the background. Great

The aroma is nice with the sour notes overwhelming the bouquet. The beer pours with virtually no head and is a brown color with hints of red at the edges. The beer is solid.. the cherries are present behind a very sour initial flavor and the sweetness creates an excellent balance. For only 5.5% the beer packs quite a sour punch but nothing excessive for sour ale fans.
Bottle thanks to Cavie. Dark red/brown color smells sour and bitter. Tastes about the same, almost like a rotten cider.
Bottle from Cavie.  Carbonated.  Reddish brown pour with a tan head.  Aroma is brown sugar, paint thinner, and sweet fruit.  Taste is sour, pucker, vinegar, wood, and dry spice.

Bottle courtesy mlunger12. Pours a murky murky maroon color with a decent sized head. For a company that gets docked for having little carbonation this bottle sure shot the cork across the room! Aroma is slightly warm notes, alcohol, dark fruit and lots of sour notes. Sour notes for sure. Dry acidic taste. Sour finish. A bit harsh.

The head is sandy with several small persistent springs from the muddy, burnt-cherry-colored body but after a couple of minutes of rest may begin to reveal a spot or two of that body.  However, a slight bump or swirl again covers the top with a layer of head.  Lacing is equally an interesting phenomenon - thick but quick.  So the body is a little homely, but the head and lacing are top class.
The aroma is cherry from an arms length (45⁰) and like cough syrup and fruit cake with a lemon hint under the nose.  There is an earthy note like wine.
Tase is salty and sour.
Palate is airy like champagne.
This is a sour ale, and these dont appeal to me as much as I would hope to like them.  They remind me too much of a pop brew with a squeeze of lemon.  OK but not worth the $14 / 375ml bottle that I paid.

Muffig säuerlicher Geschmack, in dem die Kirschnoten nicht sehr frisch wirken. Alles in allem ist das Bier wenig intensiv, auch wenn die vorhandenen Noten durchaus gefallen. Mild, weich, später harscher durch die Säure. Insgesamt habe ich hier deutlich mehr erwartet,vor allem die Intensität lässt zu wünschen übrig. Danke an den Doppelbock für das Bier. 6/8/9/9/11/9

Bottle courtesy of madirish76, thanks Rob.  Aroma is great; very vinous, sour cherries, acidic, earthy and oaky, plum, also a sweet malty note with a very faint touch of chocolate.  Pours a hazy deep reddish brown, head is fizzy and has little retention, no lacing.  Very fruity and sour flavor; cherries, some sour raspberry, sweet malt, light oak, touch of dark chocolate.  Light body, quite high carbonation, very effervescent and tingly on the tongue, dry and puckering in the finish.  Great beer, super complex and definitely worth a try.

Bottle. Pours red/brown with a small white head. Aroma is sour cherries, plums, apples, and vinegar. Flavor is sour cherries, under-ripe plums, and vinegar. Medium body with solid heat...Damn, this is good.

Sampled at 16 Tons. Dark mahogany with a reddish tint and a 1 inch cap of tan foam. Smells of oak, vinegar, cherry, plums, light funk. Tastes of vinegar, oak, light cherry and more funk. Aroma definitely better than the flavor, but both pretty solid. Goes down smooth but also less filling.
Bottle...  Poured dark, ruby with a khaki head.  Nose had tart dark fruits, well carbonated, a little hot with some cherry and grape tones.  Oak and brown sugars.  Big cherry finish.
375ml bottle, murky red pour, cherry, very oak. Oak overwhelms any other flavor, slight tart on the back end. Quite nice.

small corked and caged expensive bottle.  Pours a murky red brown, with at a first a surprisingly large, pink tinted beige fizzy head, which soon is reduced to a persistent sliver that sticks around, softly bubbling.  Aroma is mouth watering, with tones of sour cherry, sweet black cherry, warm, brown sugary oak.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, tons of acidity and is mouth puckering.  The flavor is very tart cherry and cranberry, which intensifies in its sourness on the finish.  As the beer warms, the oak comes out more, with log cabin on the finish.  Quite a nice sour, but I actually get more complexity out of the aroma than the flavor.  It is so sour that it kind of assaults your palate, and although it tastes very good it is almost one dimensional in its flavor.  Similar to the russian river line of sours, it is a big and flavorful, but not nuanced like a flemish would be.  Ultimately I am glad I tried it, but will not be back given the price tag.

Pours a completely opaque reddish brown. Huge tan head that leaves plenty of lacing on the Lost Abbey tulip. Smells like spoiled cherries, yeast, and cherry juice. Kind of a pie cherry aroma. A bit of peppery spice and woodiness. Very tart. Tastes of sour cherries, overly tart sour cherries and currants. Sour aftertaste with just a hint of fruit sweetness. Slightly salty mouthfeel with a big-copper-penny-in-the-mouth aftertaste. Not bad.

Quite a beer. The aroma of black cherries hits you as soon as the cork flies through the air.  A large white  head quicky arises. A smooth sour black cherry flavor strikes strong and last quite some time on the tongue. Very good.

Pours deep ruby-tinged mahogany into a snifter. Tan micro head with excellent retention recedes leaving trailing sheets. Sour cherry aromas. Dry with oak, cherry and sharp cranberries upfront turning to sweet summer berry seeds and marshmallow in the lasting finish.  Nice.

Bottle.

Head is initially average sized, fizzy/frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is hazy dark amber.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly yeasty (barnyard), with notes of oak, peanut butter, cherry, cinnamon.

Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately to heavily acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Pretty heavy on the oak.  Odd peanut butter note too.  Plenty of sourness, but the woody bitterness is a tad off-putting.  Solid but rather rough-edged and not terribly exciting.  Would advise using a large glass and pouring it all in one motion (without the last couple ounces), because theres a ton of sludge in this that will kick up and make the remainder pretty clunky.
booze, apples, vinegar.  brown with no head. tart, sour, cherry, lemons, plums, wood, vinegar. medium bodied palate.

Bottle at Ørsted Ølbar & Cafe, April 2011. 

Dark red/brown with a small head. Aroma of cherries, wood and with lactic notes. Tart taste that was very refreshing and drinkable, a lovely beer in my opinion.
Pours a dark brackish brown. Small white head. Sweet cherries tart and wood. Taste is tart cherries, lemons, wood. Very good palate. Overall a very good beer

Bottle thanks to Savvy1982. Pours murky brown with a fizzy heads that fades instantly. Aroma of crisp tart cherries, woody and herbal notes, also sharp tartness/horseblanket. Taste is also sweaty, lightly herbal, dry sour finish, nice sweetness. Light body, medium thin texture, high carbonation. Very nice beer. Has almost a burning sour finish.

The beer pours solid dirt brown with a big bubbly foamy caramel head. The aroma, my favorite part, is sweet, fruity, and a bit wild. The flavor is tart cherries with a strong brown ale/Flemish sour style combo in flavor. The body is rich and pleasant, thick. Almost no sweetness at all.

Bottle @ home. Pours a very deep maroon appearance with a big foamy brown head. Bretty and quite sour nose with cherries, oak, and light vanilla. Very tart cherry, vanilla, oaky, Bretty, slightly vinous flavor with a tart cherry, dry finish. Sour cherry and light woody aftertaste.
RBESG 2010, Grand Tasting, bottleHazy brown color. Nice caramel and sour aroma. Dry caramel flavor, with a nice fruity tartness. Balanced. Pleasant.

375mL bottle, pours dark reddish brown with a medium beige head. Aroma screams cherries, sourness and a prominent oak quality that lingers. Flavour initially brings out the cherries with a touch of sweetness, but this is very quickly overcome by an intensely sour / tart follow-up, augmented with the oak barrel quality that seems to only intensify this puckering sourness. Definite red wine quality as well. This isnt my favourite style, though I recognize the high quality in this quality ale.

I liked this a lot. I thought the biggest difference between this and the Russian River Sours was the palate - this one was almost spritzy, kinda almost refreshing. Lots of sour cherry, of course, plus a good bit of woody notes, too. Some nice red wine, notes, too. Very good stuff. I coulda drank this all day. Served at the VIP tent, Raleigh WBF.
Bottle. Big cork pop. Dark brown. Soft foam. Big woody cherry nose with a distinct sourness. Screaming sharp sour cherry flavour is amazing. A joyous cherry pie filling sour gooey deliciousness.
Maybe the hype around this beer was too much. Its good but not jaw dropping. Nice mix of cherry and sour notes. Not puckering sour. Easy to drink and lively.

Murky lively burgundy mahogany body. Velvety smooth creamy light tan head. Aroma - yes Flemish sour, but maybe a little bit dirtier than usual. Obviously the name is suggesting itself to me, but is it poppy seeds I smell? Taste - exquisitely made Flemish sour, very traditional. Think Supplication, maybe a little less sour.

On tap at Toronado. Murky brown with light brown head. Aroma brings some malt and cherry, and a very strong acetic balsamic tone. Flavor brings a rounded acetic bitterness, with malt undertones and complexity from cherry and oak. Im not a huge fan of the acetic sours, but this was still a good offering.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2013 one of the most complex beers ive ever had, nose has barnyard, tartness, sweet, oakyness, red fruits. Body has hazelnuts, almonds, oak, strawberries, apples, very crisp tartness. This is one amazing complex beer.

Pours a hazy, nearly opaque chocolate brown with a VERY thick tan head. The sample I got fizzed like crazy, so beware when you first pour it! Aroma is strongly oaky with malty and fruity hints and more than a bit of sweetness. Flavor has a strong oaky alcohol bite and some fruity and malty cherry tones - definitely a hint of cherry in there. Texture is fierce, attacking the tongue like a pit bull - this beer is not for the faint of heart or taste buds. This beer is intended to be sipped slowly and savored, like brandy.
This was my first and probably last sour beer.  Its like drinking a sour patch kid.  Not for me but if your into sours, apparently its a good one.

Deep amber brown pour reddish tint beige head .... aroma of sour and tart cherries, little brett and oak .....  Taste is oaky and sour tart cherries brett and ends with a dry sour light acidic finish ...  lively on the tongue tart sour and dry a great sour brew

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2011 The beer pours a medium brown with a light tan head. It rises about a finger, decent retention and lacing...strong aroma of sour oak and vinegar, not bad a little bland ... The taste is ok very strong, instant vinegar puckerer, vinegar, cherries, oak, super flavorful, this is great... this is really good. This current bottle has some age on it and is much better than a newer bottle.

AZRBWG courtesy of Daknole and Smokepot23. Draught pour is deep burnt ruby with a khaki head. Aroma shows notes of tart cherries, oak, light vinegar, and a touch of funk. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of caramel, vanilla, lemon, and a little more funk. Great, lively acidity which quickly dries up the palate and makes you want some more. I love this stuff.

Pours a reddish brown color with a thick off-white head. The aroma is sour cherries, lemon, and bread. The taste is oak, super tart cherries, and caramel. A very good sour. Im still getting used to this style but beers like this are helping me along quite nicely.

The beer pours a murky, mahogany color with a massive, beige, foamy head which settles in some time to a sturdy foam and leaves minimal, frothy lace.  The nose is very sour with prominent acetic notes, horse blanket, toasty oak presence, earthy tones, spicy cinnamon notes, cherry pits, maybe some brown sugar.  The flavor is similar but a bit overwhelmed by the high acidity; still cherry pits, some toasted oak, light brown sugar, some bretty funk, and wet earth.  The palate is light to medium, drying, somewhat silky, prickly initial liveliness, and a somewhat quenching acidity.  The finish is very quick, acidic, drying, and full of cherry pits.  Quite a lot going on for a 5% beer; very sour, very funky, and balanced by a bit of malt and oak presence.  Very pleasant to drink despite the intense sourness, but I would expect nothing less from LA.  My only complaint is that for $16 for a 12.7 oz beer, I usually expect something completely unique or something that blows me away; this did neither.

Bottle; Pour is a burnt sienna , I suppose. Very nice frothy beige head - excellent retention and light lacing in this Lost Abbey tumbler. My initial reaction? Underwhelming. The brew surely improved as I moved forward, thankfully - for the MSRP on this one, it had better. Cherry pits and vinegar on the nose; Bitter cherry, an earthiness from the oak barrels, lemon zest, and a touch of brown sugar, I suppose. What I find underwhelming is the body of this beer, as well as the finish. The center is a bit muted, really, while the brew finishes with a hint of cheese and funk that perhaps improves a bit with age?

Draft at RBWG. Pours murky ruby/garnet, with a brown hue. Thin pale tan head, ropey lacing. Nose is tart cherry, florals, big rich acid/acetic notes. Light leather, nice raspberry notes here too, some real cinnamon as well, as the beer opens up... Flavours of earth, funk, wood, cherry/berry, tart and long. Great depth. Fabulous stuff.

2009 vintage

Rich ruby red color with fizzy head that dissapears fast leaving small patch in the middle

smells of oaky vinegar, sour cherries, funk, sour apple, and a bit of fruity notes

Taste is acidic, sour cherry, not much malt. it tastes like what a sour cherry soda with no sugar added would taste like. fizzy, sour, cherry. Taste lingers but thin in the middle. a bit of funky cheesiness to this as well.

overall, not as good as i would like it to be. ive had several much better oud bruins. biggest oddity of this beer was the effervescence/champagne-like carbonation.

375ml corked and caged brown bottle.

It pours a murky reddish brown with a foamy off-white head that leaves an abundance of lacing.

The smell is full and pungent. It has some sulfuric, hard water scents. It has some brie cheese, vinegar, and some musty funk to it too. Amongst that is some sour cherry.

The flavor follows, but with a lot more sour. It is the taste of slightly bitter sour cherries, pits, stems, and all. the vinegar mixes with lemon for an acidic, tart edge. The oak is in the back with some wood and vanilla notes. The aftertaste is of Red Bull.

It is pretty carbonated, but easy-drinking.

A solid sour. And it is carbonated.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-06-2011 05:16:56

2010 vintage bottle ($15) purchased at the brewery on the release day (February 13, 2010).  Pours a lovely garnet hue with one finger of beige foam.  Aroma of vinegar-soaked tart cherries, wood, and some mild funk.  Flavor is sharp sour cherry, berries, acidic / vinegar, and dry woody tones, Leans way more toward sour, with practically zero sweetness.  Surprisingly good carbonation with a tart finish.  Pretty good, but I somehow expected more.  (477, 481)

12.7oz bottle. Pours a cloudy, deeper brown, ruby tinted body with a lively, finger-width, dense and foamy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves lots of lacing throughout. Aroma is both sour and sweet cherries with a really nice oaky wood. The sourness is moderate and not over-the-top. A distinct caramel with a light vanilla gives this a somewhat sweet malt backing. A light yeasty funk and a bit of an earth. Flavor is really nice too. Sweet and sour cherries with a bit of a juicy, light puckering lemon. Lots of smooth oak with some vanilla and a pleasant caramel. A touch of earth comes in towards the end as the cherries grow slightly sweeter with a touch of acidity too. Finishes dry with a moderate tartness and oakiness that balances nicely with a light malt sweetness and mix of sweet and sour cherries. Lengthy aftertaste following a very smooth, medium body and very soft, medium-high, somewhat lively carbonation. Overall, a really enjoyable sour. Not too puckering, but rather a solid balance between sweet and sour cherries. I like the oak and malt backing a lot. Great beer.

12 oz bottle... Not quite as strong a smell as anticipated, especially after finding out how fizzy this ale is. Still could detect aromas of fruit, oak, and surprisingly mellow and faint hints of cherry. This is a medium sour, not a full face puckerer. Kinda put off a tad by the high level of carbonation. Wonder how the bottle I laid down is gonna behave in the future? Still a very good sour, but slightly let down after waiting so long to try this one out.

12.7 oz. bottle from Bottleworks. Dark brown appearance. This beer is quite carbonated. Im worried that given a bit of time, this thing will turn into a gusher. This has an insanely pungent sour cherry and oak aroma. Ah, it smells so delicious. The sour/tart/funk aroma just crashes into my olfactories. This has a great pungent aroma. Not so tart, at first; its more oak than anything else. The sour cherry flavor lasts for a short period of time, but it has a lovely effect on the taste buds. This leaves a sour cherry pie flavor on the taste buds. I had this many months ago, and it was aged, but Im certain that I like this better. It has a bit of a caustic carbonation, but I think that this is perfect, texture-wise. To me, this is almost as lovely as an aged Consecration. Great beer.

bottle.  2011.  murky deep reddish brown under small, fizzy, tan head.  tart, vinegar, sour, cherry, oak aroma.  tart, unripe apricot or peach, some cherry.  fizzy, soda-like, light bodied palate.  dry, quick finish.  not droolingly sour but has a nice moderate tart factor.  tastes more like apricot to me.  juicier as it warms.  confused...i like the "not so sour" palate but the fizziness bugs me.

2011 Vintage, received in trade with mikedashg. Thanks!  Pours a ruby brown color with a big white head that recedes.  Carbonation continues to bubble up from the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is sour, fruity, cherry, funk, and wine.  The body is a little thin on the palate with medium to heavy carbonation.  Flavor is sour, cherry, a little alcohol.  The finish is very tart.  Not as easy drinking as some others Ive had, but an excellent sour ale nonetheless.

Bottle from Greens, quite surprised to see this one on the shelf.  Dark burnt red almost brown pour.  Fizzy white head, faded to a big ring around the glass.  Aroma was full of cherry cough drop, light caramel and hints of the sourness to come.  Delightful.  Flavors were big time tart cherry, caramel backbone, jaw clinching sour finish.  Lightly sweet and tart throughout.  Champagne like mouthfeel, fizzy and light.  Carbonation was a bit aggressive but all in all this was outstanding.

375ml.2011 vintage.Pours a deep red with an insanely fizzy red to off white head.Nose is bright cherry,heavy woody oak notes and some basement smells.Wow.Taste is ultra sour and tart cherry, vanilla and caramel oak and a perfect mouthwatering sour finish.My first perfect score.

Bottle.  Pours clear tawny with a small, fizzy beige head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toasted, dark fruit), light hops (earthy), and average esters (fruity) with notes of Brettanomyces, lactic and acetic acid, wood, raisin, and cherry.  Flavor is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toasted, dark fruit), light hops (earthy), and average esters (fruity) with notes of Brettanomyces, lactic and acetic acid, wood, raisin, and cherry.  Medium body and warmth, high carbonation and low creaminess with a dry finish.

Amazing and over the top caramel and molasses.  Crisp sour yet very cleanly and controlled fermentation.  Hardly any malt flavor comes through, yet somewhat sweet with some familiar, but non beer flavors.    A hint of ginger.  Delicious.  Like savory candy.  Amazing brew...one of the best.

10 ounce sample on tap at Public House in SF for SFBeerWeek.  Aroma has cherry, funky, acetic, and lots of cereal notes, too.  Floral, aromatic, and fruity.
