There is also some light choco maltiness.  Really freaking quaffable.  Moderately hazy, murky dark amber body with a small, off-white head.  Starts tart and fruity with some cherry flavors.  There is a good amount of acetic acid in the middle.  Late cereal maltiness with some biscuit hints.  Finishes with a lingering acidity and tartness.  Very nice.

On tap at Beer Revolution. It pours dark red with a pinkish white head. The aroma is rich, sweet cherry syrup with some tart notes and only a hint of basement like funk. Not much oak presence, in fact I wouldnt use oak as a descriptor at all. The flavor is full yet light bodied with lots of cherries. Good balance between sweet and tart. The light body keeps it from being cloying with the massive cherry blast. Nicely done.

This beer is awesome! It pours a hazy dark brown with little head. Smells like bright red fruits and some cinnamon. It tastes like sour cherry, some sugar, very light spices. Quality sour that doesnt have the vinegary taste that some do. Very good!
Dark brown and cloudy. Aroma is rich with cherries, oak, and lemon. Flavor is ridiculously tart and lemony, with lots more sour cherry flavor. Very dry. Fizzy mouthfeel.

Deep garnet-hued pour with a lazy tan-white head.  The aroma is loaded with tart balsamic/acetic character.  Loads of dried cherries wrapped around that sourness.  The palate is rich and full.  Bright vineous character through the middle.  Fairly fruity with a lot of complex fruit skin, spicy yeast and funk and soft lingering chewiness.  As it warms up the fruit seems to take on some raspberry notes.  Vineous and chewy with a little bit of soft vanilla.  As it warms the cherry notes kind of drop back and the barrel/wood flavour kind of come to the fore.  Lots of wildness regardless of the temperature.  Light pepper and cinnamon/almond flavour.  Its a lovely brew - no doubt about that.
From a bottle poured a brown color with no head.  Nice tart malty flavor with a quick aftertaste.

Bottle. 2010. Monks Lost Abbey Dinner. Pours a hazy amber chestnut brown with a soft, porous off-white head. Aroma is an insane bouquet of sour cherries, lemon zest, bitter hops, and piney, earthy tones. Body is rather light and refreshing with an incredibly sticky, biting palate. Finishes long and slowly with a tart that lingers down the back of the throat and into the belly. A truly special, amazing sour ale. Excellent

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2013 Thanks to Daknole for this!
Clear pour of dark brown with sediment that clouds things up if the entire bottle is poured.
Tart apple and vinegar aroma.
Tart sour flavor, but not like vinegar.  Dryness in the finish.

Re-rate 9/13  This has smoothed out nicely with some time. The vinegar has mellowed bringing out a bit more sweetness. Better balance.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2012 New rating:
Bottle, 2009 @ FoneFan. 9/3/9/4/18
Old rating:
Bottle. Murky brown/red with small off-white head. Flavour is malt, cherries, sour, tart and a little sweet, 8/3/9/4/17

Sampled at the SLC Holiday Tasting.  I know I have had this before, not sure why I never rated it.  Murky brown color pour with a small creamy head. Aroma of tart cherries, yeast, wood and vinegar.  Flavor is very tart and funky with loads of cherries and vinegar.  Really good stuff!
Bottle at OBriens in S.D.  Murky brown color.  Aroma of cherries steeped in balsamic vinegar.  Taste is similar.

Uncorking the bottle took a little bit of time but once I got it opened I started to salivate at the aromas I got from it. I was hit with an onslaught of cherries and sour funk goodness. I also got some woody, oaky characters as well. The appearance was dark and hazy. A brownish hue with a very thin head. The flavors were sour and fruity. Not too overly sweet, but just the right balance between sour and sweet. Nice tart after taste, which hung on the palate for a good while.
38cl, Vintage 2010, at 5%Vol, exclusive American brew, thx to Jeppe!, complex sour Kriek, balanced, cloudy, small head, good brew, yet very expensive!

375ml 2009 opened at my new years beer bash. Pours hazy brown/amber with no head and light carbonation. Aroma is very sweet with cherries and cut with a vinegar sourness with a nice woody note. Drinks very much the same as the aroma with a nice but subdued tartness that makes this very drinkable. loads of earthy tannins and cherry skins present and just perfect for this beer. finishes sweet and lasting.

Shared by a local BA on 09.23.2010.

Pours a rufous, rust-like reddish brown. A half-finger of head leaves some decent lacing.

Nose is of cherry vinegar, with minor oakiness. Vibrant berry presence. Tastes similar to a restrained version of RR Supplication for me. Theres a strong cherry presence, along with raspberries, vanilla, citrus, and a tart juiciness that reminds me of licking my fingers after picking blackberries. This beer reminds me that I was a child once. 

Sour and sweet, this is a nicely balanced Flanders Oud Bruin. I preferred this to both CdT and CL ReM, which we had this same night.

Big thanks to Kevin for sharing this one! 2009 Bottle.

A-pours an extremely cloudy lighter brown color with strong red hues shined next to light.  The head is rather thick and off white to light tan.

S-the nose has notes of balsamic up front, hints of green olives behind, there is a fair bit of dry oak giving way to a light touch of brett, light acidity and bits of sour cherries.

T-the taste has a stronger acidity and more balsamic, the oak is stronger and more present as the brett works in with the sour cherries.  There is some acetic acid towards the back that detracts from the brightness of the cherries.

M-lighter to medium body, slightly grainy on the palate and rather juicy throughout.  the finish is slightly undercarbonated and a little flabby also lacking the driness you would like to see with all the acidity.

D-this has some issues, the cherries are overshadowed by oak and acidity, notes of acetic acid in the finish and some random brett notes make this an overly sour slightly muddled beer.

I cant remember who traded this to me, but thanks! 2009 bottle. Pours a cloudy deep red with a orange hue and no head whatsoever. Aroma is full of sour cherries, quite acidic leading to a bit of an acetone note. Flavor is quite sour with sour cherries, a good amount of acid. Flavor does note become acetone though and is quite pleasant. Beer seemed to be quite flat.

Thanks bro.  Pours cider brown with a pale tan head.  Intense sour cherry aroma (mouth is salivating just thinking about it).  Very sour at first, but mellows out into the cherry but warms slightly at the end to the oak warmth.  Sharp, but with a frothy smoothness.  Sour, but not overly so, making it possible to appreciate other contributions.

Bottle shared by footbalm at the SLC holiday tasting 
Appearance: Dark brown with a nice sized off-white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Tart fruits and cherries 
Taste: Tart cherries with a slightly bitter finish 
Very nice.
Bottle at Pauls gathering. Pours darkish brown. Nose and taste of sour cherry, tart fruit and light wood barrel. Lightly acidic.

Thanks to bmanning for opening this at a recent tasting.

2009 Vintage. 375mL bottle.

A: Poured a slightly-browned red with a bit of a cream-colored head.

S: Aromas of cherry are definitely present atop some funk and vinegary acid.

T: The cherries are not as strong in the taste department as with the smell, and the slightly-puckering acidity takes over. Good balance between the sweet and tart nature of the cherries with the predominate sour qualities of this one.

M: Pretty low carbonation, fairly tart, and somewhat mouth-drying.

D: Quite drinkable. Fairly complex.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-10-2010

2010 bottle from Matt (mreusch). Translucent red-brown body, thin ring of cream-colored carbonation. Tart, but not particularly sour nose of raspberry vinaigrette. Tart body, cobwebby with residual sugars but fairly dry, fruity with vinaigrette notes. Easy to drink, good but not elite.

[3335-20100810] 12.7floz bottle. Sour Belgian yeast promises in the aroma. Hazy, dark red brown body with a medium-lasting creamy off-white head and some lacing. Lives up to all the aroma expectations with a sour light fruity yeast flavour and long sour pucker aftertaste. Medium body is a super pucker sour. Those mild cherry hints are interesting, this beer could give Cantillon a run for its money but overall is a great finish to a Belgian pub crawl!
(@ Delirium Cafe, Brussels, Belgium; w/ jerc)

Bottle tasted at Fobab 2010. Pours a medium hazy brown with a reddish hue and a small light creamy head. Aroma is sharp and tart, lemon peel, citric funkiness, nicely woody and earthy. Flavor is very nice, again heavily woody, fruity and tart, some darker fruit notes. Very sharp finish, acidic and brett throughout. Medium body and a prickly carbonation. Very tasty beer.

Dark amber pour with a quickly disappearing light brown head. The aroma has lots of funky yeasts, barnyard,  tart cherries, brett, marzipan, nice caramel malt is there too. Actually, the smell may be similar to a geuze. Very delicate. The taste is just immensely sour lots of funky yeast, tart cherries, brett, oak and vanilla, but also the more sour oaky qualities. This beer is just so very sour but very very good.

Bottle, courtesy of Phredrik!!! Dark hazy red colour with a small off-white head. Aroma is full of vinegar, barnyard, lambic-characteristics, yeast, sour grapes and berries, tart cherry, perhaps. Also some malty stuff and marzipan, along with tons and tons of sourness. Quite thick in the nose. Taste is heavily sour, really grabbing you by the balls. It also has tons of sour fruits and berries. Lots of tart cherry and vinegar. It has some of the characteristics of a regular lambic, but is considerably more potent.

Smaken är inte så fruktig som doften, men den har en välbalanserad syrlighet tillsammans med röda bär, citrus och trä, men även lite mörkare smak av plommon. Ölen har en trevlig fatkaraktär och en eftersmak som är utomordentlig god (och lång).

from erzbierschif.ch - fully cloudy reddish-brown colour with a poor head retention; sourish aroma of vinegar and cherries; fair woody notes and hints of vanilla; medium-bodied and pretty juicy palate; a solid sourness; quite dry and long vinous, sourish and woody cherryish aftertaste - marvellous!
Vintage 2010 bottle shared courtesy of Silphium. Reddish orange body with small head. Aroma of huge sourness, tart cherry, earth, funk and yeast. Flavor of huge oak, sour berry, apple skin and yeast.

(375ml bottle). Pours brown-red with small off-white head. Little visible carbonation.  Aroma of Brett.  Taste is sour. Light bodied with thin texture. Nice beer but not terribly complex.  I like this beer, but  Id take a Consecration over this any day.

Rating #2200!  375mL bottle thanks to AgentSteve!  10/9/10.  Big funky aroma with cherries, wood, vanilla, and more - slightly odd.  Huge tart flavor with tons of cherry and a hint of wood.  Amazing flavor.
Sampled at GABF on 9-18-2010.  Comes red/brown with a very thin head.  Aroma of cherries, wood and alcohol.  Tastes of very tart cherries and spices with some malt and wood.  Very sour.

375ml bottle from AmEricanbrew. Slightly hazy reddish brown with a tiny head that quickly fades to a ring. Big barnyard Brett aroma with some light sweet fruit and some lactic scents. The flavor is very tart and sour with some lightly sweet fruit and malt flavors. Medium to light body with mild carbonation and a long dry finish. This is a solid offering from the LA, it seems that lately its a gamble popping open something from them.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2010 Bottle. 2009 vintage. Pours a murky reddish brown mahagony color with really no head. Pops with very little fanfare just a little "pop". What head there is is just a wispy white head. Really nice sour aroma coming from the nose with a mix of cherries and some oak. Lots of lemon in the nose as well. The taste starts off subtle then builds to a nice level of sourness with hints of lemon and cherries. Some acetone type flavors as well. One of the most sours I have had in a while. The sourness really lingers on this one. Light mouthfeel.

1 oz sample at the GABF. Aromas of red fruits, a touch of wood and spice.  Red wine like taste with sour cherries.  medium to med-high carbonation.  Bitterness does not balance the sweetness.  Dry finish.  Thin, light body.

I had this gem at the 4th Anniversary party.

Dark reddish brown color wth a small creamy head. Aroma is a pungent lactic character and cherries. The flavor is equally grand with sour tart cherries and a subtle complex mixture of vanilla, carmel, oak aged character. A very enjoyable sour ale that leaves you craving more!

Bottle, much thanks to Cquiroga.  Shared with Ethan.  #2000.  Pours a brownish red, thin head.  Nose is woody cherries, some nice lemony acidity, some alcohol, a little medicinal, some sour orange.  Flavor is strongly tannic from the barrel, along with some very earthy cherry.  Certainly tart, primarily lemon & other citrus tartness as opposed to balsamic-ey.  There is a rich malt base in the background but it fails to tie it together.  Finish is a hodge podge of lemon, cherries & lots of tannins.
Sampled at the Great American Beer Festival on September 16, 2010.  Sour wooden cherry aroma, really wacky.  Cloudy, murky brown color.  Wow... this is one sour ale.  Sour.  Very sour and woody.

Bottled 375ml. Ordered at www.erzbiershop.ch. Complex, very inviting nose. Deeply delicious, luscious cherry components thorughout; nicely balanced and very true to the style. The finish is a bit musty, not too expressive and slightly dissapointing. A very impressive take on the style but it fails to be excellent.

Bottle. the 09 version. poured a very red/ruby color with zero head. It might have lost all carbonation but this is my first one so im unsure if this is the norm.  Flavors were completely inbalanced, with a wine fruit flavor upfront followed by a sour than beer flavor to finish. this could be just a bad bottle and I will seek another to rerate.

Thanks Reg!  For as many years as I have been drinking beer, these are starting to get real interesting.  Sour fruits and a tame vinger nose.  Refreshing, vinous, sharp sourness, but moderate cherry and wood in taste.  clean  finish.  good for afternoon session.

375ml bottle from some random place in CA.

pours a deep rich dark brown...
smells like a sour... but better than others I have had.  
blah blah blah... cutting to the chase here.

this is the best sour I have ever had.  I am not a huge fan of the style, but saw it and had to try it based on the hype... and honestly... may be the only beer I have had that is actually worth the hype.  Damn good.  if you see it, buy it.
as a sour it is the most balanced... sours, typically hit me ad dont finish well, but this one really does.

Pours a very murky pink-amber. I think my sample was towards the end of the bottle and therefore mixed with a bit more yeast. Yeasty sour aroma and flavor. A bit too unbalanced for me. With a tannic sour-bitter finish.

Dark brown and unclear. Has an off-white head, mostly diminising. Acidic aroma, fruit notes too. But the acidic is the main impression. Faint sulfur too. Acidic flavor, mouth-cleaning, refreshing. A bit astringent.
sour,dark amber, clear, minimal head, lightly bitter, medium sourness, salty, medium body, oily feel, fizzy, long finish, nice beer.

2010-08-10. Ruby tinged brown body, smooth beige head fades. 4+ Flavour is sour up front, cascading waves of variable sourness, cherry like fruit character is briskly refreshing. Muted malty undertones barely registers, giving way to nuance and complexity in the sourness that I lack the vocabulary for.  Aroma is subtle at first, musty overtones, lightly lactic but not... Cherry like fruit character, hints at sweet wood notes. 8+ Smooth average plus palate is softly carbonated and suits the beer. Feels a bit like it has the best of the union of a Flemish Red and a lambic. Very good. Bottle at Delerium Hoppy Loft, Brussels

Bottled. Pours out in a deep reddish amber colour with a small tan-coloured head. Rich and refreshing of both immature cherries and black cherries with strong notes of wood and brett. Medium-bodied with acidic and dryish notes of wood, sour cherries, immature raspberries, brett and cranberries. Long tart and acidic finish of sour cherries and wood. Explosive flavours in here!

My Bottom Line:
This powerful Sour Ale takes eloquent cherries into acetic acid for a long, sour and funky finish.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A thin ring of foam circles the cloudy dark mahogany.
-The flavor profile is much more intense than the nose, making this rather difficult to drink.
-Carbonation is very low, making drinkability even more of a challenge; this is a serious Sour Ale for aficionados only. Good thing I am one!
-The vinous finish is redolent of balsamic vinegar.
-This is not nearly as polished as their Cuvée de Tomme, for example.

Bottle.

Bottle. Pours red-brown with a small golden head. The aroma is enorumous and has got notes of wood, dry cherrys, clove and flowe water. The taste starts of sourm but then turns sweet, almost sugary. It has got sweet cherry notes but ends oaky with notes of tobacco and flower water. Dry and woody finish. The drinkability is very high.

Bottle from my good beer connection, iowaherkeye. Corked and caged. Poured a slightly hazy dark orange-brown color. The head was one finger high and tan. Attractive aroma of cherry, old red wine, distinct oak and delicate baking spices. Light to medium bodied and tart. Despite the acidity, a bit of sweetness came through. Tasted of spiced toffee, sour cherry, distinct oak, and a dash of red wine vinegar. Yum.

Had on tap at Stone Sour Fest 2010.  Easily one of my favorite Lost Abbey beers.  The Red Poppy pours with a deep brownish-red color and slight tan head.  Aroma of cherries, oak, lactic acid, vinegar, and citrus.  Taste is equally complex with the cherries being the dominant flavor with the citrus and acids backing it up.  Well balanced, finishes nicely, a true gem from Lost Abbey.

2009 corked bottle from Hoppymeal, thanks! Purple brown color. Vinous aroma with lemon, dust, caramel and confit cherries. Sour and oaky flavor with lemon, cherries, dust and caramel. Well rounded, no real sharp edges. Good complexity.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark burgundy-brown body. Thin, weak off-white head. Very little lacing, but a nice skim remains throughout.

S: Red wine, dark red cherries, oak, sweet sugar and a hearty earthy-funk.

T: Like the nose, lots of dark fruits are present. Most notably dark cherries fill out the flavor profile from start to finish. Similar to consecration, but lacking the profound tartness and sourness. A bit raw... but presents itself as a lively sweet, vinous brew.

M: Smooth, moderate tartness and sourness. Nice lingering finish. Funkayyy.

O: I enjoyed this quite a bit... reminiscent of consecration and la folie... not quite as good as consecration, but probably better than most bottles of la folie. Would like to see this one with some age on it.

It pours out a deep brown color similar to that of Coke with a tint of red residing in it. It has an alright head without much retention. The smell is pretty strong. It has the aroma of cherries with a sour undertone. The flavor is very similar to the aroma but takes the beer to another level. The initial flavor is that of sour cherries, but as that flavor fades, its replaced by a slight hint of green apples followed by an acidic overtone that finishes smooth. This is just an amazing beer. Make sure you drink it just chilled, not totally cold. And as Joe said at the Liquorette, it goes well with a dessert like a cherry pie or chocolate. I would definitely recommend this beer to anyone that like beer.

Bottled. Pours hazy, mahagony with a little, fast disappearing, off-white head. Lively carbonation. Acitic nose with yeast, wood and fruits. Sour/ sweet flavour with vinegar, wood, fruits and berries especially sour cherries. Medium bodied. Sour finish with some alcohol too. Despite Ill maybe newer get used to sour ale, I think this is a nice brew.
Cocacola brown with lots of head. Sour nose with a good amount of fruit. Very sour with more fruit flavors than the cuvee de tomme. Notes of cherry prevail. Great mouthfeel

375 ml bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours a cherry cola color, brown with a ruby tinge.  No head at all, just a small bit of bubbles shooting up the side of the glass.  Aroma is sour cherry, funk, and vinegar.  Taste is very sour, you really feel it in the back of your mouth.  Pretty thin mouthfeel, with a small hint of carbonation and bite.  Pretty good, and VERY sour if you like that kind of thing.

09 Bottle. Thanks to Alen for this one. Murky, cola-like pour with a tiny little bit of a sign of a head. Aroma is sweet and tart cherry, cherry pie, light funk, and some other fruity notes. Taste is very complex, sour, tart cherries, sweet cherries, light earthy oaky notes, funky slightly vinous notes, all the while having a lingering cherry fruit-cake note in there also. Truly a top notch beer, I really wish this was more readily available on the east coast.

Courtesy of northernbrews. Mahogany with minimal head. Aroma consists of wood/oakiness, light musty character, not much else. Flavor much the same, with light sourness, not much else going on. Oily smooth palate. Rather underwhelming for Lost Abbey.

375ml, corked & caged bottle, vintage 2010 from bev4less. opens with a loud cork pop and pours a beautiful, hazy, burgandy with a thick, creamy, khaki head leaving sheets of drippy lace. aroma is fantastic with big, tart, sour fruit notes of red cherries, blackberries, and lemons with funky, wild, bretty notes, sharp roquefort blue cheese, red wine vinegar, and musty basement overlying a slight vanilla/oak sweetness. flavor is wonderful as well with a tart, sour blast of cherries, lemons, and red wine up front that mellows quickly allowing the sweeter notes of oak, vanilla, and yeast to come to the forefront and be complimented by light brett funk, lactic acidity, and sweet-tart candy. palate is medium bodied and quite puckering with spritzy, refreshing carbonation and a lingering, dry, woody finish. overall, and absolutely delicious sour from LA.
Bottle thanks to Glen at our Carolina Sour II tasting.  Poured a dark red/brown color.  Cherry notes, light body and aroma.  Tasty, smooth, and could definitely drink a pint of it.

Tasted 2010-06-06. Courtesy of Bo. Pours dark amber with beige head. Lactic, woody aroma. Very tart, and very acidic on the palate. Well rounded, woodish, funky flavour. Exremely well balanced. Very tasty.

375 ml bottle from South Bay Drugs.  No year or batch number on the bottle but its in the 375 ml bottle that Lost Abbey formerly used, not the one pictured here.  Pours a hazy deep brown with some red highlights and a little off-white head.  Notes of sour cherries, oak, balsamic vinegarette, brett, lemon, caramel, lactic acid, and a dash of vanilla.  Medium-bodied, with a sour, funky mouthfeel and good carbonation.  Great sour ale, I need some more of these.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2012 375mL 2010 ed courtesy of ajm. Pours a deep oud brune color: cloudy deep reddish brown with a thin, fizzy tan head that has good retention and leaves spotty lace. Nose is excellent Flanders red: there are some buttery oak and bourbon/vanilla notes in the background trying to escape a massive amount of sharp lactic sourness and briny/pungent bleu cheese. Black cherry and cranberry skins abound. Taste is at first fizzy, sweet, black cherry soda with vanilla and buttery oak/barrel notes. Then the palate gets warped into massive lactic sourness, tart cranberries and cherries. Spicy oak shows through in the end. Awesome tart, all encompassing palate. Mouth- watering, refreshing, easy to love. Overall the taste is well integrated sour fruits where none take over the beer where it could be a kriek or framboise. 6/1/2010 8/4/9/4/17=4.2 375mL 2011ed thanks to tastybeer. Muddier pour with yeast floaties. Deep ruby with a fizzier, medium, tan head. Grape soda and plastic nose with sticky, old grape soda off character. Decants to thick black cherries. Taste is fizzy, neutral, lightly tart, small tart cherry. Very minerally and muddy with a lime seltzer palate. Just seems very inferior. Refreshing, but not very complex. 1/13/2012 6/3/7/4/13=3.3

Thanks to bmwgirl9606 for sending me this bottle.

2010 vintage. The beer pours a slightly hazy brown color with an off-white head. The aroma is tart with some oak, vanilla, brown sugar and cherry. The flavor is heavy on the tart cherries with some oak and lemons mixed in as well. There is also a nice sweetness that resembles brown sugar. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. An excellent beer. So happy I got to try this one.

375ml bottle of what looks to be the 2010 edition since it is the new style of bottle that LA and RR have been using. Thanks to mattolesh for hooking this up. It gushed a bit upon opening and had a super huge head. I have to ding the appearance because I got a ton of sediment all throughout this beer that was kind of chunky. The smell was sour cherry-like, not bad at all. The taste had some muted cherry qualities, dirty, funkiness a bit, and a good sour twang. This was not bad at all but compared to some of the other LA sours I was a little disappointed.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-29-2010 21:14:36

Bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. 2010 vintage. Pours murky mahogany with a frothy tan head.Sour cherry and oak aromas. Taste of sour cherries, oak and some acidic as well. Lively mouthfeel. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation, and a nice dry finish.

Tap for Brouwers Sour Ale Fest 2010. Deep brown murky pour with slight white hear.  Smell of cherry - sour and nice with earthy musk. Good acid not too little or overbearing.  compelx but easy to drink.  Signifcantly more depth than many sours with cherry.  good stuff -

From stefanje via trade.  Poured a cloudy reddish brown with a short bit of fizzy white foam.  The aroma was sour cherries, malt and softer brown sugar offering nice balance.  The flavor was tart cherry and vinegar with oak coming through a bit as it warmed.  Thin with lots of carbonation.  Not super sour and overall quite enjoyable.

750ml caged and corked bottle purchased and consumed at the Toronado Bar in San Francisco last week on my birthday.

Appearance: Ruby to garnet body with a 1 finger foamy off white crown that shows a touch of retention and lacing.

Smell: Cherries, small touch of vinegar, earth, fungus, and a good sourness.

Taste: Loads of dry sour cherries throughout with oak notes showing every so often. Small amount of brett and some biscuit malt.

Mouthfeel: lite side of medium bodied with just enough carbonation to get by and certainly more than normal for a LA brew.

Drinkability: For a tart sour and dry brew its fairly drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-11-2009
UPDATED: MAY 28, 2010 out of a 375 caged and corked, 2010 batch.  Very good!  pours a dark red with little head.  Cherries are tart.  Very refreshing.  I think this is a beer that is best fresh.

Brouwers Sour Ale Fest 10. Pours deep brown with red hue when held up to light. Small off white head initially, and quickly dies down to rest just above the surface. The nose is wonderful; sour cherries, balsamic vinegar, Brett, oak, and lemon. The taste is actually a relatively mild sour. Cherries attack your tongue and the oak aging coats your mouth with a slick but sticky Brett/lemon funk. The lactic acid burns your throat like vinegar but is very tolerable. This is an amazing sour ale. One to cellar for sure. Reminds me of RR Consecration but not in a bad way.

375ml into snifter. Pours a dark red with minimal white head. Sour cherries, funk, and bret on the nose. Moderate carbonation, thin to medium body. Flavor of sour cherries and lactic acid, delicious. Great brew

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2012 From a Tap,color is amber,fruity(cherry),white head,it?s a great sour brown ale.Do not compare this to Supplication totally different cherry sours.Updated:07/23/10 I had glass of Red poppy at Blue Palms and it was wonderful.Very fruity and sour. Updated:09/23/12 raised overall to a 19 due to being great.Brown ale with bret. Yeast and cherries.

Bottle from BOLTZ7555.  Big thanks Jason!  New packaging.  One of the better sours Ive had.  Pours a dark brown somewhat reddish color with a nice initial head that settles to a thin layer.  Big fruity and funky aroma with cherries, vinegar and cranberry.  The flavor shows funky acidic oak/barrel notes with ripe fruit; cherries, plums, lemons.  Its sour but I wouldnt categorize it as intense.  Great depth.  Some plant-like flavors mix in.  Awesome beer.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2010 One of the best sours Ive had the pleasure of drinking in my relatively new (compared to others on this site) journey into sours.  Its the whole package with the aroma, color, lively carbonation, and depth of flavor through the bittersweat cherries.  Only problem is its $15 per bottle and it goes down WAY too fast.

Update - enjoyed a full pint on tap at LA.  Seemed to have a touch less sharpness and precision than what I recall from the bottle but still really damn good with a wonderful chewy sour finish.

aroma is burnt cherry skins, crunchy vinegar.  smells gritty, pronounced caramelized wood character.  appearance is burnt sienna, wispy head, little legs.  flavor is paas easter egg kits and campfire, cherry only presents its hint of sweetness late, crushed by eye shutting sourness. wood character is not overpowering but causes the sourness to come across as impure and without focus.

2010 Bottle.  Pours a bit murky but quite red with plenty of carbonation.  Aroma is very woody, bretty, nice and tart, very full, some nuttiness, aged cherries, sharp.  Great cherry flavor, only about halfway through did some of the less desirable brett notes come through, I can see why the bottles are winning some awards this year.  Chalky finish, vitamin C aftertaste, long harsh acidic backfire, I prefer the bottle to the draft and this is much better than the last vintage.

375 ml bottle poured into my snifter.

A- Body is a very murky light muddy brown color. Pours with an approximately 1 finger white head that pretty much subsides immediately. No lacing is left behind in the glass. Cloudiness is thick and dynamic and whirls about the beer with some white yeast particles visible at the bottom.

S-An acidic tartness is the highlight of the nose and the first to hit it. Below this is a complex balance of sweet molasses, earthy mustiness, oak, and cherries.

T- Much like the nose-a pleasant sour tartness hits the front of the tongue immediately. There is a lot going on here as the cherry and oak become present underneath this and funky yeast comes through as well. The oak and cherries come through a bit more for the finish but a fantastic balance and complexity is still there. What lingers is a faint presence of the whole flavor.

P-Well carbonated and a smooth yeasty, velvety body.

O-This beer is awesome. I love it. Its a bit pricey; but well worth it (if I lived somewhere where it were available). My first of the special Lost Abbey Releases and it makes me want to find and try more of them. Very well done and perfectly drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-04-2009 18:22:10

Bottle. Sourness dominates the aroma with some cherry and strawberry notes. Cloudy brown pour with no head. Flavor is sharply acidic with some fruit character. Dry, thin palate, but full-flavored enough to make up for it.

Liquid Sunshine X  Olympia, WA  
Sour aroma, flavor this was a big beer.  Reddish brown in color, lots of alcohol and   cherry sweet you can get.  I must agree big with sweet tart flavor.  This was a great beer.

Bottle bonus thanks to Iowaherkeye!  Bottle was a slight gusher, dark reddish brown pour, and a wonderful sour and slightly fruity aroma.  Flavor is also heavy sour cherry,  little bit of dry wood, funk and finished with some great effervesence.  Solid beer, going to have to stick this on my permanent wants list.
Nose is sourness with a faint cherry sweetness. Taste is bitingly sour, almost salty. Cherries and oak aging come in at the finish, making this a complex but suprisingly easy to drink sour.

Bottle from BelgianBeerGal...thanks Amy! - Pops the cork with barely a sound and no head to speak of on top of the reddish brown pour. Oaky and sour, with earthy funkiness. Not really heavy on cherries on the nose. Balsamic vinegar, tart dark cherries, light oakiness, sweet tarts--yum. Light-bodied but a bit syrupy, with a drying effect on the mouth thats quite pleasing. Lots of citrus acidity too--lemon, orange. Tastes better than it smells, but the taste is fantastic.

Bottle from a trade with DeadGirl. Pours dark caramel color with tan head. Sour cherry and oak aromas. Flavors of sour cherries, lactic acid and oak. Mouth puckering tartness. Medium body with modrate carbonation and a dry finish. Thanks Amelia.

color is light brown and cloudy, aroma is sour and lactic- yogurty. Flavor is not too impressive- sour, oaky, slight cherries. Overall its not very pleasing, too little of too many flavors.  Bottle from a tasting with Smith4498, Legato, and Cbeers21.

Thanks to trevor211. Ruby pour with big sour nose wafting off of soapy heady. Rich funky fruit nose, big. Body is a touch light which surprised. Finishes with a rush of huge tart funk. Big sour and funky fruit. Really nice.

2009 Bottle - Thanks inflatablehair!! - Pours hazy reddish tan with a small sandy head...aroma is bright, lemon juice and sour cherry, lactic, massive oaky tannins...flavour is similar, cherry lemon and bugs, some slight vinegar and some very slight vanilla from the oak...I could very easily just gulp this down, quite enjoyable...

Really unique sour, woody aroma coming off a murky, blood orange/copper colored pour.  Quite sour at the outset followed by a dry wood, slightly charred flavor and then a very tart vinegary flavor.  The cherries here are almost imperceptible other than their contribution to the sour flavor.  Im not sure if brett yeast was used here, but it does have some of the characteristics of that.  I normally dont like beers brewed with it, but this one is done in a way that works very well without going overboard.   Definitely not for everyone or every occasion, but a very interesting and enjoyable journey when youre in the mood for it.

375ml Bottle:  Aroma of sweet and tart cherries, acetic acid, and light oak.  Poured a deep amber/muddy orange color with a small, fizzy, tan/orange, head that disappeared quickly.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of tiny and small particles throughout.  Flavor is heavily tart, and light to medium sweet.  Tastes of tart cherries, oak, wood, and acetic acid.  Medium body.  Mouth-puckering, coating texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Tart, tart cherry, oak, and light acetic acid finish.

Bottle shared with Anker. Hazy dark amber body with a small but very long lasting offwhite head, nice lacings. Aroma is sour cherries, oak, dark fruit, raisin, plums, prunes and balsamic. Flavor starts with sour cherries, oak, dark fruit, plums.

Just couldnt wait any longer.  Pours a dark reddish-brown, with ample light-tan foam and plenty of effervescent activity moving up the sides of the glass.  Cherries and sour aroma are present from more than 1 foot away.  This beer looks beautiful, smells better, and tastes...  oh wow.  Subtle start is just a touch of cherries and water.  Then the perfect amount of sour green apples kicks in, reaching a mid-palate crescendo, before settling back down to a dry, clean, balanced finish.  Absolutely wonderful stuff.  Im aging a second bottle, and now want to go get a third and fourth.  Just such a solid brew.

Pours a muddy brown with a slight white head.  aroma is of funky wood, cherry, dark fruit, and some vinger.  taste is sour and somewhat funky and is of sour cherries, some brett, dark fruits, and oak.  has a medium body with a nice high carbonation mouthfeel and a nice bone dry finnish.  overall, a world class beer.

375mL bottle, thanks to erice.  Pours slightly reddish brown with a light tan head, looks like a belgian dubbel.  Aroma is extremely sour and funky, with some sweet fruits.  Flavor is sour and acidic, with cherries, raisins, prunes, and lots of bitter citrus peel.  I feel like the bitterness, and to a lesser extent the acidity are too strong with respect to sourness, making it merely a great beer instead of a fantastic beer in my mind.

Brown pour with a thin white head.  Funky sour aroma.  Woody and grassy with hints of cherry.  Very sour flavor dominated by oak.  Subtle cherry flavor.  Slightly sweet finish with hints of coconut.  Very good sour.

Pours out a brown with lots of head. Smells like sour cherries. Taste is tart and funky woody. Flavors of sour fruit, funky brett, and oaky wood. Finish is sticky sweet and sour. Lots of carbonation. Good balance not too much sour or acid.Very good stuff

New 2010 bottle. Thanks to KieferUGA.  Pours moderately hazy reddish brown with light tan head that leaves ring around edges of glass. Aroma of tart and sweet cherries, brett, and some malt. Flavors of sour cherries, brett, and some malt. Finishes nice and sour. Lip smacking good. Dont really care for the the new LA bottles but this is a really nice label. Nice and classy.  I must say this beer packs a punch in the sweet and sour department. Good stuff.

Draft at Toronado. Let me start by saying this is the first "oh shit" beer since, well, Woodshop 5.0. Pours a murky dark amber with a thin layer of offwhite head and lacing. Nose is cherries and hint of lactic acid tart, hints of oaky wood and vanilla, light spices and something akin to cocoa. Flavor is mindblowing, light cherry tartness up front opens the door for earthy bitterness and woody leather, vanilla and oak take charge in the middle and slowly transition to light fruits/berries and very subtle cocoa and spices, finishes sweetly tart. Medium body, modest carbonation and slick texture. A full flavored and complex sour/fruit ale that dominates in all categories, far exceeds the already-solid Red Poppy, best beer Ive had in a while, good to see Tomme and crew back on top
with this one. Earlier Rating: 2/8/2009 Total Score: 3.7Pours amber/orange hue, off-white head, hazy clarity. Aroma is light tart sourness, dark fruits, light funk, brown sugar, cherries. Flavor starts with tart sourness and transitions to acetic vinegar, cherries and dark berry fruits, light funk, woody oak tones, finishes dry. Medium-bodied, moderate-high carbonation, smooth texture. Good interpretation of a Flanders Red, oak accents well, balanced sourness, easy-drinking.Earlier Rating: 2/5/2009 Total Score: 4.1On tap at OBriens. Magenta-deep red hue, thin off-white layer of head, light lacing on the glass. Aroma is sweet maraschino cherries, pie crust, fruit syrup. Sweet yet balanced cherry flavor hits initially with a tinge of lactic sourness, slight acidity in the middle with dark fruits, finishes with a blend of sweet and sour. Medium-bodied, slick texture, moderate carbonation. Overall, a sweeter/fruitier version of the original that mutes the sourness down a level, tastes more like a fruit beer (New Glarus-like) than a traditional sour, more drinkable than the original, this would be my preferred version if it ever gets bottled!

WOW WOW WOW, this was outstanding.  Pours an amber crimson body with a hazy pink off white head.  Lush cherries and raspberry notes, bacteria and leather give it this slick and lush feel.  Drying brett tone and the cherries are even more abundant just like silky melting.  Just Delicious.  Dry ripe fruit tones with musky almost grape and cherry finish. Astounding. Ive had red poppy a many of times but this Double Red Poppy was phenomenal! Earlier Rating: 6/11/2008 Total Score: 4.3Bottle and Draft at EBF.  Pours a murky amber orange body with a light head.  A sweet cherry aroma with some notes of oakiness and brettamycies.  Flavor is wour cherries, woodiness, brett all the way to the end.  
Bottle. 2009 vintage.  Pours a dark purple brown body with garnet hues and an off white thin lacing.  Sour cherry vinous notes with a light woody cherry character.  Low acidity with a lush cherry pit and skin.  Light lactic acid with a low funkiness.  A very nice brew.  4.1

Pours brown with little to no off white head.  Aroma is huge oak, vanilla, and tannin mixing with the cherries.  Taste up front is oak, vanilla, a bit of chocolate malt, leading into thick cherries and astringency from the tannins.  Excellent sour brown!

12.7 oz bottle from stefanje.  Thanks man!  This  beer pours a murky reddish brown with some bubbles on top.  Aroma of sour cherries and some lactic notes.  Tart cherry flavor with nice lactic and wood notes.  Medium tartness.  Strong flavor depth.  Nice, slick mouthfeel with good carbonation.  This has been one Ive been wanting to try for a long time and it did not disappoint.  Absolutely awesome beer.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2010 2oz tasting at EBF
Aroma : Lactic, cherries quite sour. Lots of cherries actually. 

Taste : Lots of cherries a bit lactic and quite acidic.

Overall : Quite lactic but I still liked it. Less cherries than the Double Red Poppy of course but still very fruity. Really nice stuff.
2oz tasting at NOTB as Double Red Poppy 
Appearance : Hazy dark peach-colored.

Aroma : Cherries, lactic and slightly medicinal.

Taste : Big cherries and a bit sweet. Sour and a bit lactic. Stunning fruitiness Finish is rather lactic and sour..

Overall : Awesome stuff. Better than the regular red poppy which is still pretty awesome. Total score for this version is 4.2

A: Despite a vigorous pour into my Bruery tulip, there isnt much in the way of head formation. The beer itself is a slightly muddy mahogany color.

S: The nose is nice and tart with some nice sour cherry notes along with a slight acetic acid note. Theres quite a bit of oak, which I was not quite expecting.

T: The flavor follows the nose almost exactly. Great oak and sour cherry flavors with only a touch of vinegar (which I often find a bit off-putting in Flanders ales).

M: The carbonation is quite low, lending the beer a slick feel on the tongue. The finish is nice and dry.

D: This is one of the more tart Oud Bruins Ive had, but I enjoy that. The lower level of acetic acid is also a bit plus for me.
Pours dark red-brown with a wispy halo. Aroma-Flanders-like sourness, cherry, oak. Taste- complex, well-integrated sour/cherry/wood flavors. finishes medium bodied and very nice.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2011 Bottle at LS X.  Hazed red brown with very little head.    Has a sharp, lemony sour aroma with a bit of white grape and cherry fruitiness.  The flavor is quite sour, yet well balanced.  More white grape/cherry comes through in the flavor, and this also has an herbal and earthy quality.  Finishes rather dry with a bit of oak.  Very complex and beautiful, and one of my favorite sours thus far.

Draught from Avery Sour Fest. Murky red with no head. Aroma is like pork chops sauteed in baked apples with cinnamon and apple sauce. Flavor is sour, caramel, bitter resin, grapes. Great tight finish with booze and bite.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2010 On draught at Port Brewing/Lost Abbey Brewery (San Marcos, CA): Pours out hazy brown with hardly any head. Nose of vinegar, sour, wood, red cherries, caramel and light barnyard. The oak lends an earthy touch to smooth out the sharp, acidic flavors. But initially, you get that vinegary sourness, followed by wood, caramel, and berries. Drinkability: Dry and sweet-and-sour, with almost no hops. Pairing: Tangy cheese, cherry fruit tart, or amazing with a sirloin steak and french fries. Rebuy: Yes. #291 on 25022010, DG.

Draft at Memphis Tap Room Meet the brewer night on 2/23/10.  Pours dark burgundy with very little head.  Aroma of fig, prune, along with some cherry and dry earth.  Just a hint of sweetness in the flavor, then an incredible sour cherry citrus.  This was so incredibly balanced and not overpowering.  Very clean feel with a nice aftertaste.  Even without the head, lively carbonation on the tongue.  Definitely glad I got to try this one!

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 Bottle with tomme at monks. Pours a deep Ruby red body with nice lacing and sediment.   Aroma is tart and cherries. Mouthfeel is ridiculous,  insane burst of flavor, mostly sour cherries in the start and some other riot in the finish. Deliciously paired with cherry sauce and smoked duck pate.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2010 Bottle. 2010. Monks Lost Abbey Dinner. Pours a hazy amber chesnut brown with a soft, pourous off-white head. Aroma is an insane boquet of sour cherries, lemon zest, bitter hops, and piney, earthy tones. Body is rather light and refreshing with an incredibly sticky, biting palate. Finishes long and slowly with a tart that lingers down the back of the throat and into the belly. A truly special, amazing sour ale. Excellent.

Initial Rating: 4.5 as of 2/23/2010 (Lost Abbey Dinner at Monks).

Sampled on draft tonight at The Memphis Taproom.

Pours a very dark brown with hints of dark cherry red/plum hues and golden ruby when held to a light source with a one fnger off white/light beige head that slowly settles into a thin lasting ring. Comletely opaque.

Sweet vinous aroma with a huge tart dark cherry presence with a lot vinegary funky and oaky tannis. Blots of dark fruit, especially the dark cherry accmpanied by some dark grape and possibly some raisin. Im also picking up some candy sugar. Nice combination of oak tannis, dark fruit and vinous vinegar funk.

Slightly funky medium body with a lot of tart dark fruit, vinous vinegary funk and earthy oak tannis. The sourness is only slightly lactic with lots of tart dark cherry as well as some dark grape and other dark fruit notes. Slight earthy oak tannis and sweet vinegary sourness blend together makimgthis beer very drinkable. Similar to an oude brune only with more wild yeast and a much more prominent fruit character.
Refreshingly tart. Dark brown colour and slightly more carbonated that it look. Well worth trying.

Consumed at NOTB Extreme Beer Fest. pours a murky amber/dark rust color. Has a sweet aroma with  nice sour balance (caramel and candied sugar). the flavor is sweet with a nice sour balance. A little sweet with some simalarities to new glarus belgian tart.

Totally delicious.  Super sour when first sipped it, with a warmer and sweeter aftertaste.  Foggy and dark red, resembling pomegranate juice.  It doesnt look very carbonated, but felt a little bubbly.

Thanks to boamr for this. The only complaint for this beer is the flatness. The balance is as perfect as it can be with the cherries adding the tartness to compliment the sours. The residual taste is a little oily which I thought was odd but not nearly enough to take anything away for me.

Bottle at Retorps LA tasting.  Poured a clear amber with a small off white head.  Nose is filled with notes of cherry, barrel, vanilla, caramel, and light funk.  Medium body with ample carbonation.  Flavor is sour cherry with notes of vinegar, wood, and caramel.  Finishes tart.  Awesome brew.

A:  Pours a dark amberish shade of milky brown.  Very little head.  No retention or lace.

S:  Wonderful aroma of tart red berry.  Lots of fresh raspberry and dark cherry.  Vinegar and oak play a big role as well.

T:  Very solid beer.  Tart under ripe raspberry with notes of dark tart black cherry.  Lots of acidic vinegar, and oak as well.  Very subtle chocolate notes.  Earthy, funky, and tart.  Well done.

M:  Medium in body, not much carbonation, a sharp tartness.

D:  Very good.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2013 A cute 500 ml bottle.  Pours reddish brown with a Caesar white head.  Aroma of sour and cherries.  Sourness on the tongue, above averge mouthfeel. Some fruit sugarness offsets.  This is a sipper.  Alcohol warming.
Bottle. Red brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sour, oak, berries, yeast. Flavour is sour, apple, sweet, pinapple , cherries , vinegary. Nice sour beer. Fazinating beer.

Its hazy, red-brown without much head. The aroma has notes of vinegar, sourness, wood, berries, caramel and light barnyard. The flavor has initially vinegar sourness, that grows less dominant after a while, and it has notes of wood, caramel, berries (the cherries are very weak) and the finish is dry and slightly sweet. The overall impression is most of all a bit too strong sourness, wood and a little berries. Not my style, but I recognize, that this is one is quality.

Bottle, 12.7oz, 5%. Its a clear, brownish golden beer topped by a minimal off-white head, soon transforming into a small rim of bubbles. Really lovely nose, fruity and vinegary, with raspberries and some cherries. Berryish flavor blending raspberry and cherry, and a good vinegar addition. Quite fruity too. A bit thin mouthfeel maybe, but nicely puckering and nose-rinsing acidity. Sour finish. Nice! 090925
Muddy brown with absolutely no head. Basement aroma - clear notes of oak and cherry, The flavour is sour, earthy and leathery. Not bad, but then again not nearly as good as the best Belgian lambics.

( 375ml 2009 vintage thanks to mar) Ruddy orange brown with odd floaters and no head. Nose of tart cherries, wine barrel and other very tart sour flavors. Taste of sweet tarts, very sour cherries and ascorbic acid. A little undercarbonated with a nice sour finish. A great beer!

bottle, pours dark brown with red hues and a thin off white head.  Tart red fruit and wind yeast sour nose.  Bittersweet and tart cherry juice flavors with some plum and tart lemon in the finish.  Nice and mellow, the sourness does not kick you in the face.  Carbonation is very light and provides a soft mouthfeel.  Very nice!

Bottle thanks to BelgianBeerGal. Pours a red color with a little head to it. Has a sour cherry smell to it. Taste is about the same as the smell. It a nice sour overall but I would of liked it a little more sour.

A strangely looking murky reddish brown color with a minimal tanned head that quickly fades away to a small ring of lacings.

The smell is of tart cherry notes and an interesting mix of bretty funk and oak barrels. The barrel notes are more prominent than expected. Hints of other fruity notes and caramel reminiscent of an Oud bruin. An interesting and to large extent good smell, but its not excellent.

The taste is actually quite acidic with sour cherry notes from start to finish. Some complementary caramel-like sweetness. Notes of wood and oak barrels. Mild funky notes and notes of berries. The finish is tart with notes of brett and cherries and a hint of minerals. After a while, the acidity mellows out a bit, letting more sweetness come through.

The body is quite light, too light I think. The carbonation is slightly too mellow, I would have liked it to be a little livelier and sparkling.

A good beer, but not fantastic. Ive come across many comments about this one comparing it to a lambic, but too me, it is more of a sour, fruit-infused Oud bruin than a fruit lambic. 2008 edition: Rusty mahogany. Vigorous poor yields a small tiny-bubbled head. Acetic acid, prune, port-steeped raisin aromas with subtle notes of iron, oak, almond (cherry pits), minerals, and leather. Minor oxidation (sherry). Soft prickles of loose carbonation. Soft and well-rounded, initially, with a tart and juicy interplay of lactic and acetic acid. Oak exercises restraint as while uniting with the brisk mineralic twinge which absorbs much of the resounding juiciness. Snug oak-derived tannins contribute faint vanilla, though the wood acts merely as a platform so as to highlight rather than pummel the lustrous fruit character. Malt is dry, though virtually nonexistent. Cherries showcase immense depth, all the way from the slick texture of the skin and the succulent flesh, on down to the light almondy character extracted from the pit. Finishes raspy with iron along with a brush of oaken dryness yet still slick and fairly moist with lingering cherry skin and acetic acid. While I certainly enjoy the juicy lactic and acetic notes, Id love to see those particular characters complemented by some phenolic/Brett action. Nicely structured, as well, though more a *bit* more dryness would help. Pretty good stuff.
